content:
Posted: February 22
												An interesting mix of roguelike, turn-based strategy, and tower defense, Dungeon of the Endless crash-lands a group of futuristic adventurers into an abandoned facility on an uncharted planet.  Each floor of the facility is broken up into rooms, and opening a new room begins a "turn" in which monsters might spawn, skills recharge, and resources are generated.  When monsters attack they make a beeline for the player's escape pod, which must be defended with strategic placement of the controllable adventurers and turrets placed in between waves.  As a roguelike no two runs are ever the same, with different dungeon layouts, characters, and items completely changing the best method of survival.  The game even offers online multiplayer with each player controlling a single character; a simple change that makes for an enjoyable collaborative strategic effort.  Now, Dungeon of the Endless is NOT for everyone, as the high level of strategy, planning, and resource management required for a successful run (not to mention the possibility of bad random chance ruining said successful run) makes for a very slow and methodical game experience that can feel more like staring at a spreadsheet than a dungeon.  That said it is an expertly-crafted game jam-packed with content and possibility for the aspiring chess master to sink their teeth into.

content:
Posted: September 3, 2014
Early Access Review
								A surprisingly deep strategic dungeon defense game with excellent pacing, sense of progression, and replayability. Premise: Your spaceship crashland on an unknown planet. You find yourself burried into an unknown facility, trapped, with only the hope of find an exit out of this treacherous dungeon. WIth a team of heroes, you must plan a strategic escape by moving your ship's powercore to elevator. Along the way, without knowing where your destination lies, you must open doors to dark rooms populated with monsters, hazards, or if you are lucky, treasures, recruits, resources and special events. One of your main decision lies in using the game's main currency to power rooms, preventing monsters from spawning. You also have to allocate resources to build defenses, improve your hero, and invest in long term tech growth. ===Review===*Note: this is a beta review. Gameplay:+++ Great balance betwen Macro and Micro management. Macro involves resource allocation, where and when to power/unpower rooms, tech progression, defense placement and combination. Micro involves allocating heroes to point of defense, creating chokepoints, using abilities, etc. This is a huge plus because at any given point in the game, you will always make meaingful decisions for which you can be rewarded or punished.+++ Great Pacing. Pacing is determined by opening a door, which begins a new round: you gain resources, monsters spawn, you fight, etc. You can open as many doors and at whatever speed you wish; in doing so you dictate the flow of action. There's definitely as sense of joy as you become better at the game, especially in regards to making efficient decisions and this becomes every evident in your pacing.+++Customizable experience = Replayability. You can choose heroes and your spaceship in this game, which modifies the starting and persistent conditions of the game. For example one of the spaceship in the game changes the number of starting heroes from two to four and boosts their damage, but disables certain resources/defensive structures. +++ RNG = Replayability. Many factors are random as you progress through a level, such as what items you find, when/where you find merchants, which/when recruits you find, what special events occur, which monsters spawn, level layout, etc. --- Uneven difficulty. Do not make this mistake of using difficulty metric from other games. EASIEST difficulty = NORMAL,  play on easiest difficulty to learn game's mechanics. But once you've learned the mechanics, you'll find that easier difficulties take away from the play of the game, as abundent resources, weak monsters invalidates the need for better strategy.Strategic Elements:+++ Monsters have differentiated goals. Different monsters will prioritize different targets, be it your heroes, resource producing structures, defensive structures, NPCs. As such their pathing is different. Learning such differences adds depth to  the game.+++Well defined Hero roles. Most heroes in the game are specialized, which means that for any given situation you'd prefer some heroes over the rest due to their stats and abilities. This is good because your hero composition matters. +++All Hero stats are relevant. This is impressive because 99% of games out there get this wrong. +++All but one building in the game is useful. --- Why is this building in the game???--- Need more environmental hazards, such as cloud of slowing.  I feel like this aspec has so much potential, as it makes certain locations more strategic. ---Needs more NPC types to protect. The merchant is great for the game since the bonus of keeping him alive is huge. But the game would be better if there are more NPC types that offered different benefits. Interface+++ Clutter free--- Skills need more information--- Need customization hotkeys --- Why is the Inventory window separate from hero window Visuals+++Great color pallete+++Stylized characters --- hard to tell towers apart if build in very close proximity---hard to tell some lower tier offensive buildings apart from others due to their small sizeTheme+++ Interesting character bios+++ Flavorful naming schemes--- Wierd assortment of obsolete technology and futuristic technology for item choices.  Verdict:Without a doubt, this game is worth a buy if you are interested in the defense genre.  Though it's hardly fair to pin this game down to any one thing in particular, as you'll find many elements from different genres that will add to your enjoyment, be it strategic planning/resource management, hero building/progression, basebuilding/defense, and a small slice of MOBA-esque hero micromanagement. In the end, all these things would be meanlingless if they didnt add up to a cohensive whole, but in this case, they do, and the game shines because all the parts ultimately add up to form a more intricate and interesting whole.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 13, 2013
Early Access Review
								I'd be hesitant to offer a recommendation on a work in progress (something the game advises youf upon login), but this game really got its hooks into me from the first play through which is probably reason enough to give a recommendation. Let me first be clear though that the current version only offers 3 levels and so this is akin to paying for a demo with the promise of more to come.The simple premise of opening doors and dealing with the consequences offers a surprising amount of variety given the fact that the events are randomly generated (or so the advertisng seems to make me want to believe), and the presence of resources that must be managed effectively. I consider this second element something of a boon as any kind of game where you build a base (mostly Real Time Strategy, but this 'Dungeon Defense' can fall into the same trap) will immediately set me to designing the 'perfect base' which takes a lot of time and tends to keep me from enjoying all that a game has to offer. Of course, if you happen to like doing such things, there's no sandbox mode, so keep that in mind.In the present [0.1.1] version you must be mindful of Dust, Industry, and Food. Dust powers rooms and, if it falls to 0, marks the end of the game. Industry allows you to build improvements that do everything from improve your production to offer defense. Food heals, hires, and levels the characters you have under your control (starting with 2, maximum of 4). Resources (including character health) are restored when entering a new room, and so some element of guess work is involved in best preparing yourself for whatever the next room will bring.Success, as far as it can be measured in such a game, is achieved by picking up your crystal - the heart of your base - and bringing it to an exit once it is discovered. Easily the most tense moments of the game are created by the waves of enemies that attempt to prevent your heavily encumbered crystal holder from accomplishing this goal. Assuming the crystal makes it to the exit intact, you'll be presented with the next dungeon with whatever resources you had previously (as you might suspect, and I learned the hard way, committing all of your resources to achieving this goal is ill advised).There are possibly two considerations a potential buyer might want to be aware of before jumping in with this title. Similar to the publisher's previous title, Endless Space, fairly significant elements of the game don't seem immediately clear to a first time player, even after considering the tutorial. For instance, I assumed a character's level automatically increased by collecting food (it doesn't), and it took me until the second play through to both discover how to accomplish this and equip the items I was hoarding in my inventory. Fortunately, this title has very simple controls and so it is not unresonable to assume that most players would be able to figure these things out eventually, but this process of discovery may not to be all players' tastes.Second is simply the question of value. Is the game worth your money, and if so, does the Founder Pack confer enough benefit to justify the slightly higher expense. The game itself is definately worth it, and I myself went for the Founder Pack. FIrst, consider that the majority of benefits come from owning previous, and anticipated, games by Amplitude (and so you are likely to already be an owner of these games, though my copy came with a 1/2 coupon off for Endless Space and its expansion, so if you're not an owner, you have a good excuse to become one). The other major benefit is the participation in the G2G program. On this front I would caution that I was a long time owner and player of Endless Space and have not yet taken advantage of the points I have earned for that title. I also encountered difficulty when attempting to use these credits (resolution pending). So if the G2G content alone is the reason for upgrading, I would suggest going with the Pixel Pack. That said, as an owner of Endless Space, I don't regret my decision to go for the Founder pack.All told, I think this a very engaging title that is simple to pick up but doesn't go stale. Even in its unfinished state, it's a nice looking game with a wonderful soundtrack (another feature it shares with its predecessor Endless Space). I'm really looking forward to what the developers have in store as they complete their work on the title, but I absolutely feel like I got value for the money I spent even in its early access form. Check it out if you're looking to try something new.

content:
Posted: December 12, 2013
Early Access Review
								Its challenging and interesting. With game elements such as Tower Defense and Turn-Based/Real-Time components, the current alpha will take some thinking to get through, even if it is only a few levels.The goal of the game is to explore the "Dungeon" to find the exit point. The exit point isnt for your characters, but rather an Artifact that you must protect and transport. The Artifact isnt solely for the Capture the Flag purpose, it must be defended whilst you are exploring the dungeon, since all damage done is taken out of an important resource that can only be gained through exploring, killing enemies and selling items (from what I have discovered).By Turn-Based, we can classify the turns as the opening of a new room. You build up your defenses and manage resources/heroes in real time, with no chance of being attacked. As soon as a door is opened, there is a chance of gaining loot, meeting a character, or initiating a wave of aliens. The aliens may not only come from that room, but other rooms that you have opened that have no line of sight. So by using the free time, you prepare your defenses for the eventuality that the aliens come. You move your characters in Real Time and can build structures during alien waves (albeit at a slower rate) to defend.When you are completing the goal of transporting the diamond to the end point, it triggers an All or Nothing alien swarm spawn, with large, endless waves of aliens preventing you from completing the final goal. Yes, you may get the diamond to the end, but can all your heroes survive? Their deaths will carry on to the next level, and you need all hands on deck. Did you use too many resources levelling up/healing or building structures? The leftovers also carry over to your next game. The graphics are not really an issue. There is a factor of fun I really enjoy. I am not sure if multiplayer could be incorporated into this game, uunless it is a coop - pvp fight against the aliens, cooperating or fighting to get the artifact to the exit first. Many hopes for this game that it turns out as well as i had fun playing it.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 7, 2015
												Dungeon of Endless is a fantastic rogue-like game. the pixel art style in games is getting old, however it doesnt take away from this title. Starting out with 2 heroes ,you must travel through a maze-like dungeon consisting of, I believe 12 levels to reach the exit.  Along the way you must build machines at way points you find ,to produce industry,science,and food. these are all used to build defenses,level up your heroes.and unlock technology. Finding items along the way to equip in your heroes inventory is rewarding.Finding and unlocking additional heroes along the way is satisfying as well. Traversing the dungeon is done by unlocking doors, each door unlocked may reveal a treasure chest, merchant,monsters,heroes,resource bonuses, Dust,or nothing. Dust is collected by opening some rooms and by defeating monsters. Dust is required to power a room. you can only buid machines and defenses in rooms that are powered. Some rooms are powered by themselves,however you may not power a room if it is not  connected to a room powered between it and yout starting point. Thhere is a technology that will allow this, but the cost is expensive. You will rarely have enough Dust to power every room. Unpowered rooms will spawn monsters that will attack you ,your technology or your crystal. The Crystal is always in the room you start in. once you find the exit, one of your heroes must carry the crystal. Of course carrying the crystal will severly cripple that heroes speed. you must defend the helpless hero as he/she makes thier way to the exit room. once there any heros in the exit room with the crystal may exit that floor and continue to progrees the dundeon, While you take unspent resources with you ,finding Dust seems to diminish as you reach the final handful of levels. The levels and items are procedurally-generated ,making  for worth playing again and again. Leveling up your heroes is fun and unlocks new abilities. I had a bit of a hard time learning the game. I did have to watch some play throughs before understanding what was really required to be successful. Once you grasp  the resources, how to get them, and what they are useful for  the game actually plays quite simple. While it plays simple Dungeon of Endless is hard and tense at times. You will die often and have to start over, however unlocking new heroes for your next playthrough is rewarding even in defeat. 4/5

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 18, 2015
												Imagine FTL crash-landed into Dungeons of Dredmor, and you could begin to explain Dungeon of the Enedless.  Sort of.  Amplitude has merged serveral genres into one in DotE (roguelike, 4x, squad tactics), and with stunning results. Don't let the mix of genres intimidate you. I'd never touched the 4x genre before, and found the basics of the game easy to learn.You begin by choosing two party members as your escape pod crash-lands in a hostile environment. The goal is to get your crystal (i.e., what powers all of your rooms and strucures) to the exit of each floor.  As you navigate your way through 12 levels, you will find a variety of equipment, teammates, and problems to solve (namely: how to keep your crystal from being detroyed).Each door opened constitutes a new turn, and that's when resources (industry, science, food and dust) are gained. Industry allows you to buiild, science can be spent on researching new modules, food levels/heals/recruits heroes, and dust powers rooms. Because rooms are powered by dust, you'll want to watch how much you have, as unpowered rooms will spawn enemies on most turns. Enemies will navigate toward the crystal in the most direct path available, so plan your defense as your explore.Choose your party members wisely, use their strengths to your advantage, and be careful about opening that next door. Some heroes are faster, tougher or more potent in combat than others. Some excel at a single role, while a few are flexible enough to do whatever the case calls far. Knowing when to man a defense and when to retreat will be important. A handful of heroes have the "operate" skill, allowing you to buff whatever major module they're manning. Make sure to pause often in combat -- it can save the life of your teammates when enemy waves become overwhelming. Death is permanent, so don't be stingy.Your heroes aren't alone in this, however, as you can build and research new structures (Major and Minor modules, both offensive and defensive) to help you succeed. Major modules are mostly for gaining resources, while minor vary from standard turrets, defensive buffs/debuffs or even healing teammates on enemy kills. Keep an eye out for how to gather as many resources as possible, as they will prove vital to success. You can't take your built modules with you, but you will retain any resources accrued.As far as sound and visual design go, DotE is a pleasant and consistent 16-bit palate.  The visuals are highly stylized and consistent, and the soundtrack will keep reminding you of tunes that could just as easily be from SNES titles or FTL. Thanks to unlocking new characters, difficulties and escape pods, the game is chock full of replayability. Online co-op should further bolster the game's lifetime, but I haven't had any experience with it to comment on.It's not as frustrating (read: unfair) as FTL, but still challenging enough to leave you feeling satisfied... even on the "Too Easy" difficulty setting.  Highly recommended.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 2, 2015
												Dungeon of the Endless (DotE) is said to be a merge of dungeon crawler and tower defense, with random level generation and RPG elements. But is it really so? Let's find out.The game starts with two characters chosen from a pool of sixteen (many of them locked at the beginning) on a crashed spaceship. Their only source of energy is a crystal they must protect at all costs, and their objective will be to escape the "dungeon" where they have landed. The dungeon has twelve random generated floors, each of them considered a level. On each level, you explore the rooms in search for an elevator to take you to the next one. But it's not enough to find it. Once you find the elevator, you have to carry the crystal there.Both in the exploration and the transport phases, monsters will attack you, but in different ways. Here comes a key element of DotE: the dynamic combination of real-time and turn-based gameplay. A new turn begins each time you open a door. At this moment, you receive resources and monsters spawn. From this point, you control your characters in real time to fight the monsters or build new defenses. When you take the crystal to carry it to the elevator, the game becomes full real-time, with monsters spawning continuously until you reach the level exit. Or die.The game takes elements from different genres. First, you have a party of up to four characters. You start with two and recruit more during the exploration. Some will die, and death is permanent, so you'll need to hire replacements. Each character has three item slots that can vary from one to another, in which you can equip stuff found on chests or bought from merchants. They also have a particular level system: you don't level up by fighting monsters and getting experience points, you level up by spending food (one of the resources avaliable) on the characters. Higher levels lead to better stats and new abilities, both active and passive. Characters are different enough to have different gameplay styles. Next you have the resource system. There are four resources in this game: industry to build things, science to research new things, food to heal and level up your heros, and dust to lit rooms. Lit rooms allows you to build things in them, and also prevents monster from spawning. You can increase your production in any of the first three resources by building modules, but dust is only obtained when found through the dungeon, and resets at every new floor. There are also a lot of minor modules to build. From stat bonuses to plain offensive towers to enemy mind control modules. DotE comes with two difficulties: "very easy" and "easy", which in fact mean normal and hard, respectively, and also some pods that determine certain gameplay changes, like no health regeneration in exchange for better heals with food. This, in combination with the different character choices and research decisions, help to increase the game lifespan. In my opinion, this is a highly original game, an unique combination of genres with an identify of its own, and probably one of the best indies of the last year. It's hard and it's punishing, and many gameplay aspects are left for you to discover for yourself, but beating it is really rewarding.

content:
Posted: March 18, 2016
												In Dungeon of the Endless, you play as survivors of a spaceship prison, destroyed while in transit.  Your escape pod crashes in to a dungeon, and your objective is to clear all twelve floors and get the hell out. You start with two squad members, and can pick up more (to a max of four) as you go along.  The gameplay itself is very in-depth, and would require a windy explanation.  There are plenty of reviews that have done that, so I'm going to keep it short and let you know just what kind of game this is.Game elements that Dungeon of the Endless does well:Roguelike (with permadeath)Tower Defense (a variety of towers that you'll need to complete each floor)RTS (with pause, research and resource management)RPG (character leveling and equipment)Squad-based CombatEach of those elements exist here, and they're all handled perfectly.  The closest thing this game has to a failing is the weakish story, and limited dialogue.  Some of the dialogue is a little poorly written, as well.  The characters are crazy cool, though.  And there are lots of them to unlock.  Don't buy it for the story.  Buy it because it's a jack-of-all-trades video game that masters every job it sets out to accomplish.Warning:  This game is hard.  The two main difficulties are Very Easy and Easy.  In 70 hours of gameplay, I've managed to win twice.  On Easy mode.  And I've loved every second of it.

content:
Posted: December 19, 2014
												Truly bizarre game, but one that works really well. This is a strange combination of tower defense, a roguelike, and Gauntlet; it sounds strange, but it's great fun to play. You have a team of heroes whose job it is to find the exit to the level, and get your power crystal thingy to that exit without it being destroyed. Sounds simple, but there's a lot of hidden complexity here. You can use your crystal's energy to power rooms in the dungeon, which stops creatures spawning there, but there's never QUITE enough energy; you need to decide which rooms should be powered, which rooms can be allowed as spawn points, where to position your heroes so they can stop monsters spawning, defend against those that DO spawn, protect the crystal, reach each other if they need help, gain extra supplies by 'operating' machines, etc. Each hero has a unique combination of abilities (and items you might find) which can help them specialize into particular roles.Sounds tedious, maybe, but it's fast-paced and fun. And extremely @#$@ing frustrating.cheap + fun = well worth a play

content:
Posted: March 28
												Absolutely brutal, but (mostly) in a good way.  Will keep you opening doors for hours.DotE is essentially a Tower Defense game, albeit one with a couple of central conceits that combine to make for something quite a bit more interesting.  You play as a set of 2 heros chosen from a fairly sizable roster, each with unique stats, skills, strengths and weaknesses, tasked with taking a McGuffin from Elevator to Elevator whilst waves of monsters that spawn every time you open a door try to either kill you or destroy said McGuffin.  Opening doors also generates resources, each of which is seperately produced and used for specific tasks, all of which are important in their own way.  The game is a constant balancing act between building generators to get more resources vs. building defenses to keep them from being destroyed, leveling up characters whilst keeping enough food on hand to keep them alive, funneling monsters to choke points without getting them over-run, and positioning your heroes to deal with oncoming waves as you open doors in search of the exit.The fact that the dungeons are randomly generated - along with the massive number of unique heroes to choose from - greatly extends replayability.  Unfortunately, monster spawns have also been partially randomized, resulting in occasionally running into floors that feel downright unwinnable.  The game WILL kick you in the balls on occasion, but because of how much the game depends on strategy and approach it hasn't left me feeling cheated more than a handfull of times in several hundred playthroughs.Definitely worth picking up.

												The game, Dungeon of the Endless was made using the Unity engine and was developed by Amplitude Studios,and goes for the price of 19.99 US Dollars,The game came out in october of 2014 and is planned to have a xbox one release later this year (2015).The Endless Dungeon is a Strategy,Dungeon Crawler,Tower Defense game.You play as a crew that crashed there ship on to an unnamed planet after the crash of your ship you have to go through the many floors of the vessel until you beat that ship,once you have beaten a crashed ship you move on the next one and so on. In each ship you come across a crystal,that you have to protect it and in order to go to the next floor you.As far as gameplay goes you have to set up several sections of industry, science,food,LAN for the ship.The industry lets build up turrets for your defence against the plenty of hordes that will come.The food generators let you make food that you heal your hero with.The science produces as in the name more science which lets you upgrade the other modules.The LAN module Adds 120%/140%/170%/200% to all module's defense.The last main module is the Tactical HUD which adds 18%/21%/23%/26% attack power to all heroes on the floor.There is also a multiplayer so instead of contolling two charaters by yourself you can work as a group of four (Maximum).A few disclaimers,The standard price for the game is 19.99 as said earlier but I wouldnt reccommend buying it for that much,The most I personally be willing to pay for a game like this is around 10-15 US dollars.I personally purchased the game for 6.49 US dollars for the Endless Sale where all endless games were going on sale.Another slight problem with the game is the elevator at the end of the level on my first multiplayer game on The Endless Dungeon i had grabbed the crystal and went to the elevator and traveled up by myself to the next floor my team was left behind.Overall though I have enjoyed my time playing this game.I would reccommend if you are a fan of indie games,old school pixil graphics,and tower defence game.My overall rating for the game is a 85/100.

content:
Posted: February 20, 2014
Early Access Review
								Dungeon of the Endless has been one of the most pleasant gaming surprises I have had in the last months. I usually don't trust early access games, and honestly, I am not too fond of pixelated graphics, but after reading the different positive reviews from other gamers, I decided to give this game a try.And what a nice surprise it was, up to the point that I have decided to make my first review in Steam to support these developers and their game. As you might have read, this game is a mix between roguelike and tower defense games. Though they are two very different genres, the gameplay is so smooth that they blend together seamlessly.The difficulty is hard, but fair. You are going to die a lot, but you will learn something new from each run. Everytime you play, you will perform better and better (or at least learn new tactics or approaches). The randomization of the levels and heroes makes this game replayable many, many times. However, this randomness can also provoke that some of the levels are more difficult (or easier) on every run. Overall, I really love this approach, as makes every game very different from the previous ones.In spite of being an Alpha, the game is very playable, and in about 6-9 hours you will be able to finish the 5 levels that are currently developed. However, you will probably come back for more runs.Pros:- The gameplay is a blast, even in this Alpha stage.- Excellent blend of tower defense and rogue-like games.- A game that makes you think and choose wisely your actions. One mistake can doom your run.- Very nice art style.- Randomness makes this game very replayable.- Distinct and interesting heroes.- Nice difficulty level which makes every advancement very rewarding.Cons:- Pixelated graphics. It is something personal, but I don't like them very much. However, as I priorize gameplay over them (and the art style is very nice), it is a minor complaint.- Randomization can make a level very easy, or very difficult (it is a good thing, but also a bad one). For me, it is also a minor complaint, as I love surprises...As you have seen, I don't think that the difficulty level is a Con. I prefer the game being difficult (or at least having that level adjustable), because I think that games should not be a walk in the park.Very nice game, and definitely recommended! Thumbs up for the devs, and I am eager to see the new surprises you have in development for us in the following patches!

content:
Posted: October 22, 2016
												A unique roguelike that skirts the boundaries between tower defense and RTS, with systems and energy management systems that all work together to create a challenging game set in the Endless universe that continues to get expanded with lore and crossover references that make the unvierse feel cohesive and connected even though the games take place eons apart from each other. A squad management systems allows you to recruit new party members as you go and level them up, forcing you to decide between new unlevelled prty members as you find them, and the team you've started the game with and invested points into. You need to carefully balance your team between members thta are good at combat, good at scouting, and good at taking care of the modules and towers you place down to help you when fights get overwhelming.On top of this, the game sports excellent multiplayer at the expense of taking away the pause function - but with a second or third or fourth set of eyes, you shouldn't need to pause. Right? ... right? (no)The music and dungeon ambience and aesthetic are fantastic as well, giving the right environment to crawling thorugh all of these old abandoned facilities and parts of the planet as you try to escape, and shutting down everthing but one sepcific route as you try to carry your Crystal through, FF: Crystal Chronicles style lightnig the way, gets incredibly intense and nailbiting. There's also unlockables available about all crew members and monsters to draw you into the world more and learn more about them.And all of that is just on the basic default space-pod, which has no modifiers that change the way the game works on a basic level. There's more that change how every run works as you unlock them, and an Endless mode to see just how far you can go.Great game, and the only reason I haven't  played it more is because of a billion other games to play.

content:
Posted: January 14, 2014
Early Access Review
								Think FTL, but better, and different, but still hard as balls. You Start DotE with two randomly chosen heroes and your generator in your crashed ship, with a door to a randomly generated dungeon.Open the door, explore the dungeon, build modules to collect resources, use resources to level up heroes and build turrets  that attack, increase defense, heal or cast status effects. Discover merchants and buy better gear, blueprints for better turrets. Find new heroes and recruit them to your team. Find the exit to the next level and get your generator there safely to escape.At this stage in the Alpha there are a few features locked, and as far as I can tell there is only 3 levels available but that is more than enough, because you will die. You will die A lot. As I said, think FTL. Other than that, it's fantastic. Look gorgeous and plays great, honestly had you told me this was the end product I would still have bought it and played it for hours. 100% recommended!

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2014
												An enjoyable RTS / Tower Defense / RPG hybrid with roguelike elements that will sink in your head for days. The gameplay is original, yet extremely challenging even on the lowest difficulty, the art-style is gorgeous and minimalistic, and there is tons of content just thrown at you at every turn. It's also story-lite so there's no walls of text thrown at you constantly.The game has a steep enough learning curve, only giving you a short tutorial on the basics, requiring you to figure out things for yourself. You start with two heroes, but eventually you will unlock up to two more hero slots as you find them in the dungeon, with a total of 16 different heroes available to choose from. Resource managing is key in Dungeon of the Endless. If you want strong characters, you'll need to build food modules, if you want tons of laser cannons to stop wave upon wave of enemies, you will need machinary resources. And if you want access to additional modules ranging from decoys, lasers, bombs, then you'll need to gather science resources.(Here is the part where I explain how to play this game, making it even more confusing.)The game has a unique "turn" system, designated by a door, i.e. when you open a door, a turn will pass, giving you resources based on modules you have built. Anything can happen during these turns. A wave of monsters can surprise you, power can go out, you may uncover a buff crystal or a research post, or a shop where you can spend a specific randomly chosen resource on some neat stuff.The objective of the game is to find the exit in the dungeon, allocate a hero to carry the crystal at the start of the level, and escort them to the exit, while of course, being bombarded by enemy waves. Rooms can be lit up using "Dust", the primary resource in the game. It's collected from enemies and certain rooms when opened. Dust is also the crystal's health, so if attacked, you will lose dust, thus losing power in rooms.Lighting up the rooms stops enemies from spawning during turns and the "final" phase, but also allows you to place modules on the dungeon floor at the cost of machinery resource.The game is perma-death, so if your crystal is destroyed, if your heroes die, or if the hero carrying the crystal dies, then it's game over, and back to level 1 again. There is a number of different "pods" you can choose from, all with various difficulties and requirements, so there is plenty to mess around with here.There is so much more to this game, including levelling up your heroes, learning new skills, abilities, picking up or buying/selling items, weapons, armour and accessories, triggering random events and most importantly, taking a whole bunch of risks. It's one of the most perplexing and gripping games I've played in a long time and you should buy it when you can. (There is multiplayer, however I haven't got around to taking a stab at it yet,  but when I do, I'll update this review.)

content:
Posted: October 26, 2014
Early Access Review
								Let me state something that may seem a bit funny.  When I saw DotE hit Steam as Early Access, I hoped for a new dungeon crawler like Diablo, Path of Exile, Torchlight, and others.  What I got wasn't really what I was looking for and I put it down and did not touch it.  Fast forward to months after the purchase.  I decided to load it back up and give it a chance, due to the fact that I was starting to really get into rogue likes.  I didn't understand it, but I kept pushing myself to learn what makes this game work and if I can like it.  I started to understand and I started to like it, but I was terrible at the game and put it down again because of how bad I was doing.  Fast foward now to the present where I absolutely adore this game.  I finally understood the idea of modules, currency, dust, what stats do.  I'm still bad at it, but it's due to my skill and not for the fact that I originally hated it.  The art style, music, controls, mechanics, etc; everything here to make Dungeon of the Endless a fantastic title.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2016
												So let my start off by saying I love this dev, unabashedly.  I think they're great.  I think Amplitude is fantastic and I will still buy any game they come out with.  This game is terrible to me.What is there to do in this game?  One simply right clicks and then awaits the result.  I don't see any real depth to this because I'm just sitting here watching my heroes do their hero things and the RNG spawn mobs wherever it feels like spawning them.  There is no actual gameplay, it's just the power of your right click against the RNG.I don't leave very many reviews at all, but this one was a special kind of insidious.  The reviews are great, and I think for the hardcore roguelike player this game might have a lot to offer.  However, I work a full time job, I've got family stress, I'm in my late twenties.  I can't enjoy a game that makes me die repeatedly to learn what I need to do anymore.  At the same time, this game that makes me die repeatedly just plays itself.  There's no story (like Spelunky), no uniqueness (Curse of the Necrodancer) or class replayability (Risk of Rain).  It's just a little game, but god it's not worth the frustration to me.I refunded it.

												This game has the ability to make time pass very fast. I'm thankful to the pirating community for being able to try this gem of a game before I bought it. I don't have the best computer so it's a gamble to purchase games, and living in a small town without any place to work has made game purchasing hard as of late. So when I was working I made sure to pick this one up to have support the authors. That's something all of you should do, if you pirate a game and enjoy it, then buy it!         Anyway, this game is best described as a tower defence roguelike dungeon crawler. I'm not always in the tower defense mood, but when I am I am glad to have this game to go to. My only grief is the same grief I have with most tower defense games. Once you figure out a working strategy the challenge vanishes. Thankfully there are other game modes to play with, some of which don't allow me to do my winning strategy. (Boy did my heart sink once I figured out the strategy to just breeze through the game though)        I recently got caught up in a nearly 16 hour straight gaming session with this one (which is when I figured out my strategy) and got a little burnt out and probably wont be playing it again for some time. I'm still glad to have it in my library and if any further updates come alone to freshen things up a bit more I'll certainly hop back into it.        Oh, and one more grief is the online play. It's best to play with friends that you know already and to communicate using skype or something. I've never finished to the end on any online play, someone almost always drops out after the second floor, if not the host dropping everyone immediately after game start. I once made it to the eighth floor with someone online. But what started with 4 became 2 after the third floor. If there was a way for the resources to be divided up among the players or something different than the current system it would help a lot. I've had games that quit immediately because someone used up a resource right away or built a module that made the host upset. All and all, unless you have friends like I said before, just don't worry about the multiplayer.           In all if anything I wrote sounds appealing then go for it! Especially if it's on sale. I really need to stop getting inspired to write a review right before I go to bed. I've been nodding off while writing this and forgetting what I just wrote. So sorry if this is a bit jumbled. It was written by a very sleepy man who for some reason, decided now is the time to share with the world that I like this game! Keep up the good work game making team guys who made this!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 24, 2015
												An intriguing blend of tower defense, rts, and dungeon crawler, that suffers the foibles of all three.The art style is crisp and reminiscent of FTL, while bringing tidbits of lore from the Endless Space universe. Meanwhile, its cast is relatively new, so there's no worries for those who aren't a big fan of the 4x game Dungeon of the Endless is deriving its lore from.Gameplay largely functions in an RTS micromanagement style. Where in an RTS you may be controlling dozens of units in multiple control groups, Dungeon of the Endless plays in a more hero-themed style, controlling only up to four characters at a time. Multiplayer games allow players to reduce the number of units that must be micromanaged, and a four-man band can each have one player, allowing for very simple or very complex micro scenarios.Main stumbling block of the game is the newly implemented multiplayer. Because turns are based on doors opened, and because certain things, say, research, demand a number of doors to complete--and because there are a limited number of doors in a floor, and increasing threats in deeper floors--playing with new players is an experience in frustration, as they will be compelled to progress turns through a desire for exploration--whereupon overwhelming numbers of enemies can spawn.Additionally, DotE suffers from an overdependence on a turn-based resource pool, and thus the management of 'build orders'. While the build order/research dynamic works fine in an RTS, where you're in a technology arms race against an opponent in a sportlike setting, the opposite is the case in a team-based dungeon crawler. Since as many as four people can be in the same party, there's often a pressing urge to 'do' something, when the gameplay demands the players instead take their time and plan for the whole group. Depending on the player personalities, this can lead to an 'Armchair General' type of situation, where one player makes the decisions, while the rest either simply nod and follow along, or stand around waiting to defend against spawned monsters from unlit rooms. Not helped by this is an "Operating" mechanic on many of the characters, which incentivizes players to hold their ground and utilize a resource building to produce extra resources, instead of exploring seperately. Essentially, every move through a door is a collectively agreed-upon move for the team, or else resources dwindle, and monsters become overwhelming.Some of the spawning mechanics probably need a little tweaking. As much as a roguelike should encourage preparation, improvement, and memorization of what threats do what, Dungeon of the Endless has a bad habit of rolling the dice on what kind of enemies will pop up on a floor, and some combinations are downright diabolical given lack of dust, a resource that itself is RNG-limited. For instance, one run with a friend spawned massive hordes of yellow enemies that attack the floor crystal, reducing light levels--but the floor also spawned rapidly dashing enemies that FLEE combat, to bust open far off doors, to allow for more monster encounters to occur. Making matters incrementally more difficult, the floor also determined it would spawn an enemy that debuffs the PCs attacks, making juggling all three issues together impossible, for our group. While this is of itself forgivable for a normal roguelike (teaching the player that one particular threat must be seperated and singled out, or that preparing the right technology can avert a wipe), the fact that such a well-synchronized set of monsters can spawn en-masse on the roll of a die after hours of gameplay, and without much warning, does not mesh well with a tower defense/rts style. For layman's reference, imagine if Plants Versus Zombies threw hordes of Gargantaurs and Bungee Zombies at you, before even warning you that the upcoming waves would have them, or even showing you what one did, before sending dozens your way. There is potential for a similarly devastating scenario, in later floors of Dungeon of the Endless.All in all, it's a fun and new idea, and I'd love to see it refined into something different. Imagine a more straight-forward dungeon crawler that used this real-time, multiplayer mechanic, without the resource climb. Play this game for how it pieces together some diverse, disparate mechanics functionally and attractively, but don't be too disappointed when it starts to grow repetitive in that old, wave-after-wave, tower-defense way, or just pisses you off with an all-in "zerg rush" via AI mob spawns, that makes you want to take a break from it for awhile.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2015
												WARNING: So here we are, Dungeon of the Endless. A very different game from Amplitude studios; who specialized in 4X games (Endless Space, Endless Legend). And while this game has multiple elements of those previous games and 4X games in general, if you are looking for a 4X Game, this is not your pickup. If you are looking for a good rogue-like, a good tower defense game, or a mix of both and some 4X elements, this is the best pickup for you on the market.Settings: The settings are useful and helpful, as everyone has their own preferences. Overall positive. This goes for the UI of the game as well.Story: There is little direct story in this game, such as in The Binding of Isaac, but much is hidden in the lore and different unlocks you find in the game. These will not be further discussed, because spoilers.Gameplay: Time for the meat of this review. The gameplay is relatively simple. Your characters progress through rooms on twelve different floors, each floor progressing in difficulty. There is always a chance for monsters to spawn, and you will fight them. But the big part of the game is the four major resources that come into play. Here they are:Industry (Gear Icon): Industy is used to build things (notably modules): They can generate other resources, or defend rooms.Science: Spend science to research new modules.Food: Levels up/heals your heroes.Dust: Does not generate per floor, but is picked up. Used to light rooms.If a room is not lit, monsters might spawn in that room. So yeah. You're going to need some defenses. There is a crystal in the starting room, once you find the exit, you must take that crystal to the exit. You can't leave until the character CARRYING the crystal enters it. Once the crystal is picked up, in every dark room monsters will spawn.Elements: The rogue-like element is pretty obvious. The 4X elements of resource management and production, and how to spend them is super important. But tower defense is pretty simple. Build things that help heroes, or hurt monsters, so that they can't get to your crystal. When the crystal is hit, you lose dust. When the crystal dies, you lose. When all the heroes die, you lose.Difficulty: It is an odd game in difficulty. At the start, there are two difficulties: Too easy and Easy. Too easy after a few games to get the hang of things becomes too easy. Easy is brutal, and requires you to scrap for resources, mangage them incredibly well, and then most likely die to some fatass punching your crystal.Replayability: Yes. It has proceduraly generated floors. And it's a rogue-like. Never heard of a good rouge-like without replayability.Conclusion: This game isn't often what people are looking for, especially fans of previous games by Amplitude. But this is a fantastic blend of multiple genres, including the dying tower defense games, and the somewhat bland 4X games. This revitalizes these elements in a unique blend that requires the player to be smart, quick to adapt to situations, good with spending resources and leveling the hero, which brings some RPG into the game, and not getting too frustrated when that fatass kills your crystal three games in a row because you didn't upgrade those claymoar mines on floor seven to get a HUD module that no matter what you do keeps getting destroyed halfway through the floor because you haven't saved up enough industry or science to buy or research better protection, and now one of your heroes is dead because there wasn't enough food to heal her, and oh my god it's Midnight. I need to sleep. Well maybe let's have one more go.

If you are looking for a good rogue-like, a good tower defense game, or a mix of both and some 4X elements, this is the best pickup for you on the market.Settings: The settings are useful and helpful, as everyone has their own preferences. Overall positive. This goes for the UI of the game as well.Story: There is little direct story in this game, such as in The Binding of Isaac, but much is hidden in the lore and different unlocks you find in the game. These will not be further discussed, because spoilers.Gameplay: Time for the meat of this review. The gameplay is relatively simple. Your characters progress through rooms on twelve different floors, each floor progressing in difficulty. There is always a chance for monsters to spawn, and you will fight them. But the big part of the game is the four major resources that come into play. Here they are:Industry (Gear Icon): Industy is used to build things (notably modules): They can generate other resources, or defend rooms.Science: Spend science to research new modules.Food: Levels up/heals your heroes.Dust: Does not generate per floor, but is picked up. Used to light rooms.If a room is not lit, monsters might spawn in that room. So yeah. You're going to need some defenses. There is a crystal in the starting room, once you find the exit, you must take that crystal to the exit. You can't leave until the character CARRYING the crystal enters it. Once the crystal is picked up, in every dark room monsters will spawn.Elements: The rogue-like element is pretty obvious. The 4X elements of resource management and production, and how to spend them is super important. But tower defense is pretty simple. Build things that help heroes, or hurt monsters, so that they can't get to your crystal. When the crystal is hit, you lose dust. When the crystal dies, you lose. When all the heroes die, you lose.Difficulty: It is an odd game in difficulty. At the start, there are two difficulties: Too easy and Easy. Too easy after a few games to get the hang of things becomes too easy. Easy is brutal, and requires you to scrap for resources, mangage them incredibly well, and then most likely die to some fatass punching your crystal.Replayability: Yes. It has proceduraly generated floors. And it's a rogue-like. Never heard of a good rouge-like without replayability.Conclusion: This game isn't often what people are looking for, especially fans of previous games by Amplitude. But this is a fantastic blend of multiple genres, including the dying tower defense games, and the somewhat bland 4X games. This revitalizes these elements in a unique blend that requires the player to be smart, quick to adapt to situations, good with spending resources and leveling the hero, which brings some RPG into the game, and not getting too frustrated when that fatass kills your crystal three games in a row because you didn't upgrade those claymoar mines on floor seven to get a HUD module that no matter what you do keeps getting destroyed halfway through the floor because you haven't saved up enough industry or science to buy or research better protection, and now one of your heroes is dead because there wasn't enough food to heal her, and oh my god it's Midnight. I need to sleep. Well maybe let's have one more go.

content:
Posted: May 1, 2014
Early Access Review
								The last patch for this title, as of this writing, was 0.5.2, so things may have changed as you read this review.Even if things have changed however, this is still a very solid recommendation. I had this game on my wishlist from the first time I saw it, and struggled with whether to get it or not as I have been burned by other Early Access titles before. But this game blends several genres together beautifully; roguelike (or roguelite, depending on how picky you are at naming it) along with tower defense and turned based role-playing.The story is pretty barebones at this point; you're on a prison ship, and it gets shut down and overrun by monsters, and thus you have to escape. For some reason that isn't explained, you need to take a crystal (presumably a power source?) with you. The crystal serves as your "base" hit points, along with a power source and currency. You start with two heroes out of three to start with, and as you progress you can unlock additional heroes by means of first finding them at random and surviving three straight floors with them in your party. Each 'turn' is the opening of a door. In between you can build modules to provide one of three resources (food, science, industry) or specific modules to attack incoming enemies, increase attack power, defense, or even debuff enemies. This is where the tower defense element comes in because you have to manage the resources you have to make sure the crystal is properly defended, and your resources aren't unlimited. Once you run out of rooms to open on the current floor, you're out of resources.The roleplaying elements come from finding equippable items, and using your food resource to level your heroes. Combat isn't involved, as your hero and the enemies take turns swinging, and while you can heal them mid-battle with food, that's about as involved as the combat gets.The roguelike/roguelite elements come from the fact that each floor is randomly generated, so you don't know what enemies you'll find, where the exit is, where any additional heroes are (f any), etc. Also the fact if you lose, that's it. If you meet the criteria to unlock a hero they will be available upon starting a new game but that's it. I should also point out that the only thing that carries over between levels of the dungeon is the hero's equipment and levels. It sounds complicated, but it's easy to figure out after spending some time with it. The music and sound is fitting, not really exceptional, but the graphics are very pleasing to the eye. But in this case it's the gameplay that sells the same. It's very good right now and should only get better from this point.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 18, 2015
												Very cool game. I didn't expect as much depth to it as it had. It was also freakin' hard! The first dungeon has 2 difficulties, "Too easy" and "Easy", which really rather felt like "Normal" and "Hard mode". I haven't managed to clear it on Easy yet (so, "Hard mode"), but the too easy variant was indeed pretty easy to beat. I never ended up bothering much with the other dungeons, I tried them but in the end the original dungeon was the most fun.There's lot of variety in the game. You can go at it from a lot of different approaches (Tower-Defense style or rather Hero-Defense style for example) which isn't explained in the game but you figure it out on your own, or through YouTube videos.Multiplayer mode adds in a lot of fun and really enhances the game. You have to decide together with someone else which way to go, what to build, which stuff to research and how to spend your resources as efficiently as possible. Also you cannot pause in multiplayer, which saved my life very often in single player mode. That makes it a lot more challenging, but since more players can watch over things it's well-balanced.Multiplayer mode does have one big downside: it's messed up resource system. It would've been more fun if resources were either shared or something else. Now each player has their own resource pool of which the income is based on a formula that goes (normal resources gained/amount of players), rounded up. Usually I ended up passing all science resources to one player, that would do all research and then I'd do all production so they'd give all industry resources to me. Every round. Super annoying.All in all, definitely a fun and challenging game. I'd recommend it to others, both single- and multiplayer. It's easy to pick up, hard to master, and throws a serious challenge at you. It's definitely worth the price, compared to what you get.

content:
Posted: October 14, 2016
												The complexity of a Four-X game with the  brutality of an old Arcade game, plus Tower Defense. You wander through dungeons opening doors until you find the exit.When a Hero dude/dudet opens a door, monsters spawn in dark rooms and go to "the Crystal" (which acts as a power source for lit rooms) with the intent of destroying it. You can place modules in lit rooms to defend them from monsters parading towards the crystal thing. Modules cost resources generated by opening doors; some Large modules increase the resources gained when opening doors. When you survive 12 floors, you win.That's the beef of the game. The rest is details, but that's where the puzzle/experience of every game is too, even 4Xs. This game's beautifully modular design makes tiny DLCs feel revolutionary. It's awesome.Not reccommended for Pixel-Art tourists; you'll be savagely eaten by the game's mechanics. If you're patient, you'll like it though.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 17, 2015
												At first with the presentation and the graphics I wasn't sure to test it.  Then I went in it because I also do bitmap art these days.  I was delightfully impressed in the free week-end.The learning curve is pretty intuitive in comparaison of the over complicated tutorial and 1Gig heavy game it was pitted against.  In the same time it is just enough complex to had made me growl the very first 4 times I tried to clear the first level because I didn't figured out yet how to use the towers/turrets.  Once that is understood, you can start to scheme so much for how you want your game to go and level out your characters, it is amazing.  And yes... another of those game without survivability with saves at each 2 seconds at the will of the player.  The character dies and the game is over. It reminds me of Hired Gun with a totally different angle and mission. In fact a single mission.  But good luck to beat the game I am pretty sure once at last level it will be a heavy tower defense labyrinth to get trough.Each character have different specialities and texts and must cooperate to get alive to the surface.  I do REALLY like it!Addendum:  As I looked back with nostalgia with the time I've spent on this game, I recalled that just at the end of the free week-end I've learned how to level up my characters and also, the multiplayer coop is also great.  ^^

content:
Posted: January 9, 2016
												This game has the ability to make time pass very fast. I'm thankful to the pirating community for being able to try this gem of a game before I bought it. I don't have the best computer so it's a gamble to purchase games, and living in a small town without any place to work has made game purchasing hard as of late. So when I was working I made sure to pick this one up to have support the authors. That's something all of you should do, if you pirate a game and enjoy it, then buy it!         Anyway, this game is best described as a tower defence roguelike dungeon crawler. I'm not always in the tower defense mood, but when I am I am glad to have this game to go to. My only grief is the same grief I have with most tower defense games. Once you figure out a working strategy the challenge vanishes. Thankfully there are other game modes to play with, some of which don't allow me to do my winning strategy. (Boy did my heart sink once I figured out the strategy to just breeze through the game though)        I recently got caught up in a nearly 16 hour straight gaming session with this one (which is when I figured out my strategy) and got a little burnt out and probably wont be playing it again for some time. I'm still glad to have it in my library and if any further updates come alone to freshen things up a bit more I'll certainly hop back into it.        Oh, and one more grief is the online play. It's best to play with friends that you know already and to communicate using skype or something. I've never finished to the end on any online play, someone almost always drops out after the second floor, if not the host dropping everyone immediately after game start. I once made it to the eighth floor with someone online. But what started with 4 became 2 after the third floor. If there was a way for the resources to be divided up among the players or something different than the current system it would help a lot. I've had games that quit immediately because someone used up a resource right away or built a module that made the host upset. All and all, unless you have friends like I said before, just don't worry about the multiplayer.           In all if anything I wrote sounds appealing then go for it! Especially if it's on sale. I really need to stop getting inspired to write a review right before I go to bed. I've been nodding off while writing this and forgetting what I just wrote. So sorry if this is a bit jumbled. It was written by a very sleepy man who for some reason, decided now is the time to share with the world that I like this game! Keep up the good work game making team guys who made this!

content:
Posted: August 17, 2016
												Horrible, unbalanced, irredeemably broken, counter-intuitive game design that doesn't work. Yes it's "unique," but so is a bicycle with cubes instead of wheels. Does that mean it works as a game? No it does not, contrary to what the♥♥♥♥♥♥eating lowlifes at charlatan blogs like RPS might tell you.I was initially drawn to this game because of its intriguing promise of a tower defense dungeon crawler. "How the heck would that work?" I asked myself. DoTE's answer was: "lol it doesn't, but thanks for the money." What we have here, ladies and gentlemen, is your classic Emperor's New Clothes situation. 90% positive reviews, naturally, because none of the brain surgeons writing reviews for this abomination wants to be the first to ask why the Emperor's strolling around in the nude. The RPS monkey ♥♥♥♥ers gave it a rave review based on ten minutes of cretinous button mashing at a trade show so it can't be bad! If your first instinct is to dismiss this as a cracked design due to its many fatal flaws immediately apparent to even the most casual connoisseur of game design, allow me to say you would be perfectly right in saying so.What's wrong with it, you may ask? Where do I begin? It's a mix of real time and turn based which may strike you as totally counter-intuitive at first. Oh, and you can pause. So... why is there an RTS component again? Presumably the developers didn't have the imagination to create a turn-based TD game and instead forced RTS onto it because of the conventional wisdom that all TD MUST be in real time. Just like all shooters must be in first person, herp derp. But I'm getting away from the point. This isn't necessarily a fatal flaw in the design, even if it is incredibly clumsy. The fatal flaw is introduced in the interaction between the game's janky real time combat and the permadeath system. As you might expect from a game advertising itself as a "roguelike dungeon crawl" this game has permadeath, which is fine. The problem is in how easily your characters (in whom you're compelled to sink huge amounts of resources. Did I not talk about that? There's no XP. Of course there isn't! Instead you have to spend the Food resource to level your characters. Because every game has to have that FIDS resource system crammed into its design.) die with ZERO warning. You can look away for a split second to build some towers or some♥♥♥♥♥♥and one of your characters will be dead when you focus on them again. Great game design. They aren't incapacitated or require reviving or anything, they are immediately DEAD when their hp goes down to 0, effectively ending your run. Contrast with the clever character permadeath system from something like Darkest Dungeon.I could go on with other similarly horrid examples, but I'll spare you. Broken, non-functional, non-viable, vomit-inducing game that should've been aborted in the prototype stage, but instead astonishingly made it to release. I keep trying to find some good in it but come up empty handed at each attempt. And finally, the lazy hipster pixel graphics as the icing on this particular♥♥♥♥♥♥cake. Last time I give this studio any money, and I've already given them plenty.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 26, 2014
Early Access Review
								Rogue Like Dungeon crawler.You end up on this planet after "your" (aka the ship you were on as staff or prisoner) prison ship got attacked and destroyed. Dont worry you managed to launch a escape pod and escape death... for now.Your only option once landed with 2 survivors is to open the door out the unknown... with a minor hope of a ticket somewhere away from this dangerous place.Economy is split between Four things.Food to level and heal your heroes.Science to remove cooldown on abilites or research new modules that will make your journey easier (to make it possible that you might survive without good luck or being veteran to the game)building material (dont recall correct term) That you build modules that increases one of these three or many minor one with offensive defensive or boosts to the room you build them in.And finally we have Dust... Your best friend. Without this materia darkness will consume the entire level. Also the merchants love Dust since it is also the currency in this game. So will you spend some dust to buy a new weapon or armor? Or will you light another room so unknown lurkers cant spawn there to attack you that might occur when you open up yet another door into the unknown? The option is yours, but know this; To many dark rooms will for certain mean a bigger fight once they come... And they will come for either your blood or powercrystal (your dungeonheart where dust is stored).There is currently a bunch of diffrent unique heroes(more being added all the time), you start with a few ones, all being unique. But during your journey you will run into outsiders, good and twisted characters, all ready to join you up to a party of max 4. Keep them alive for 3 levels and your permantly unlock them for your next round... which open up the game depth even more. The levels is randomized, however the number of doors isnt. (currently)This game currently in beta, the devs got a very clear structure of what they want to do and they have frequently updates for the game.  You shouldnt be to worried about this game not being finished or ending up as a mess.Currently the game is fun enough and with more content being added it refreshes the replay value of the game.I highly doubt you gonna regret getting this game. But if your in doubt, do more research or wait until complete.Personally I recommend this game.

Posted: June 25, 2015
												Dungeon of the Endless is a really kickass RPG/rogue-like Dungeon-Defense game. It's very fun with multiple people but there are a few issues, you see, to unlock a character (even in multiplayer) you have to hold that character in your control for 3 floors after finding them, but only you unlock them. The only other issue I've had is that every time we get to around Floor 10-12 the game auto-crashes or will freeze, or the elevator simply wont trigger, so at this current point it is unwinnable for me or my friends. Maybe we're the only ones with this issue, but i've come to doubt that. Other than the previous listed issues, Dungeon of the Endless, like its' other games, kicks total♥♥♥♥♥ fun gameplay, cool items (and item descriptions) cool characters with great backstories, good OST, and most of all, Endless Fun.

content:
Posted: January 30, 2015
												Amazing game. Simple concept, defend yourself and your resources while trying to advance through oncoming waves of enemies. Dungeon of The Endless is a great mix of turn based strategy with tower defense mechanics. It's an oddly addicting game that will have you saying, "just one more floor", again and again. This is especially fun if you have played a bit of Endless Legend as the lore carries between the two. Unlocking heroes and new ships is very addicting and well worth the price. Multiplayer is great and probably the highpoint of this gem; getting a great team of heroes is the most amazing feeling. I can highly recommend another title from the masterminds at Amplitude, they have gotten it right yet again.

content:
Posted: April 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								WHat is there to say about DotE?Its good.! Its a Roguelike, its a Tower Defense, It uses Exploration as a limited resource. Only other game I have seen pulling this of was desktop dungeons, and that was allways a tense fight there.The graphics - Lovely. Its all Pixel graphics, but they still look so Good. I mean, It is Pixels, but then again they actually look like something other than blocks.Gameplay : It takes a little getting used to, but a lot can be found out in a few sessions of trial and error. still think this needs a Tutorial and/or First Time Tutorial floor, but you can only deliver what you have and since not all systems are 100% done and are subject to change, building an extensive tutorial wuld be a bit in vain. But the system at all is simpleyou build stuff, you open a door, you see whats inside - Monsters, Relics, Survivors, Loot - and you gain resources from your built stuffI also love how they got an EXP-less Levelling system. Thats what one of the resources is for. You give them enough food, and they Level up. But the limited building space, the limited Dust to activate rooms to build stuff in them and the fact that you have 3 resources you have to take care of make this game a really hot decision sometimes.Sound - The music is Gorgeous. Need I say more? I love me some good music in gamesOverall - for an early access game it is quite good and delivers a lot of content already. a good bunch of loveable heroes, a hard make-you-thing management system and most of all, tons of Rougelike Try againsy fun, since the game may end up playing the "Diablo 2 Wheel of Skills" with you and your building/resource decision(To explain the reference, Diablo 2 was a Clicky RPG with a multitude of classes and different skills. However, most builds that bring you through the game just fall short at the final boss. Means you could breeze through the game with a necromancer summoning skelettons wreaking havoc, but on the final boss they will be killed of way before they reach him. Not to forget that he one hits you as average necromancer. That boss was the "Is your Skillset viable?" moment. And no, the only way to respec was to use a trainer/Savegame editor. If you didnt want this, its start the game from scratch )

content:
Posted: March 26, 2014
Early Access Review
								Rogue Like Dungeon crawler.You end up on this planet after "your" (aka the ship you were on as staff or prisoner) prison ship got attacked and destroyed. Dont worry you managed to launch a escape pod and escape death... for now.Your only option once landed with 2 survivors is to open the door out the unknown... with a minor hope of a ticket somewhere away from this dangerous place.Economy is split between Four things.Food to level and heal your heroes.Science to remove cooldown on abilites or research new modules that will make your journey easier (to make it possible that you might survive without good luck or being veteran to the game)building material (dont recall correct term) That you build modules that increases one of these three or many minor one with offensive defensive or boosts to the room you build them in.And finally we have Dust... Your best friend. Without this materia darkness will consume the entire level. Also the merchants love Dust since it is also the currency in this game. So will you spend some dust to buy a new weapon or armor? Or will you light another room so unknown lurkers cant spawn there to attack you that might occur when you open up yet another door into the unknown? The option is yours, but know this; To many dark rooms will for certain mean a bigger fight once they come... And they will come for either your blood or powercrystal (your dungeonheart where dust is stored).There is currently a bunch of diffrent unique heroes(more being added all the time), you start with a few ones, all being unique. But during your journey you will run into outsiders, good and twisted characters, all ready to join you up to a party of max 4. Keep them alive for 3 levels and your permantly unlock them for your next round... which open up the game depth even more. The levels is randomized, however the number of doors isnt. (currently)This game currently in beta, the devs got a very clear structure of what they want to do and they have frequently updates for the game.  You shouldnt be to worried about this game not being finished or ending up as a mess.Currently the game is fun enough and with more content being added it refreshes the replay value of the game.I highly doubt you gonna regret getting this game. But if your in doubt, do more research or wait until complete.Personally I recommend this game.

content:
Posted: December 17, 2013
Early Access Review
								Review written as of 0.1.1:This game is definitely in alpha, and, as a warning, only 3 stages of the game will feel VERY short. It only took me a couple hours to experience just about all of the in game "behind the door" events, level up all the different heroes, and unlock all the different structures currently available. Ordinarily I would not recommend this title for the average buyer, since there is so little content existing at the present moment. However, as an owner of Amplitude Studio's previous title, "Endless Space", I know this developer as a consumer-oriented, professional studio that sets deadlines and pushes themselves to continue creating content for their games well past the "we could just abandon the game, take the money, and run" phase. I have lots of confidence that the content will continue coming. You will just have to be patient for crucial game elements like the whole research system, all character abilities, the full character roster, DEAR GOD MORE FLOORS PLZ AMPLITUDE, etc...The graphics and colors of this game are very pleasing to the eye, and shadows look great. FlyByNo is an AMAZING in-house composer, and his work on this game is just as great as his work on Endless Space. I do not know who does the writing at Amplitude but whoever it is, they put such flavor into every tooltip, every item description in all their games that you'll find yourself reading every word that finds its way onto your screen, no matter how dull you may expect the description for an item like "T-Shirt" to be. The founder edition comes with 50% coupons for Endless Space and the new Endless Space expansion (since buying the Disharmony expansion was in my plans already, this practically offset the cost difference between a Founder's Edition and Pixel Edition alone) for a total of about $20 in savings. The Founder's Edition itself costs $20 normally ($15 on sale now) so if you were actually thinking about buying Endless Space and it is not on sale, you may as well buy a Founder's Edition of Dungeon of the Endless and apply the discounts to maximize your Steam Wallet.In short, this is a fun and unique game with lots of easily visible potential that it doesn't live up to yet. If you are not confident in this developer's ability to deliver content steadily and stay committed to their titles, you will likely feel ripped off for the amount of content currently available and I'd recommend waiting for an official, non-early release. Otherwise, you'll enjoy this, but slowly, and you will wish there was more content available just because you're so enticed by what already exists.
