content:
Posted: April 29, 2015
												Dungeon of the Endless, to put it simply, does everything right.At its heart, Dungeon of the Endless is a relatively generic hero-based tower defense game. You defend your core node against spawning armies of increasing difficulty while building modules to defend and support your heroes. If this was all Dungeon of the Endless was, it would really just be another Kongregate tower defense game.However, the mechanic that Amplitude chose to focus their core gameplay on is exploration, and what a glorious implementation it is.  I've always been a fan of games that use exploration as a resource mechanic. I enjoy puzzle games and this one simple mechanic can turn nearly any game into thought-provoking puzzler.The premise of the game is simple. You're on a ship and you crash land. The only thing salvageable from your ship is a power source. You need to protect this power source and drag it through each of the levels until you reach the top and can be rescued.Of course, it's not that simple.Dungeon of the Endless uses a resource system comprised of industry (for building things), science (for learning how to build things), and food (for keeping your dudes alive and leveling up). You gain these resources by opening doors (exploration). There is also a concept of Dust as a resource, which you find in some rooms or from some monsters. By allocating Dust, you can light up different rooms in the level. Lighting up rooms does a few things: powers your devices in the room and prevents monsters from spawning. However, you don't have enough Dust to light every room, so it becomes a puzzle of what rooms to light up and/or occupy to minimize the spawning enemies. When you do find the level's exit and you plan to try to move your power source to it, the fun truly happens. From every dark room, enemies constantly spawn. The person carrying the crystal moves at half speed, so it's up to everyone else to defend that person until they reach the exit and your team can leave the level.Speaking of your team, you start with two dudes. They all have different abilities and different stats. Over the course of the game, you can use food to level up your guys (up to a max of level 15) which helps their stats, gives them new abilities, etc.All of these concepts work completely and are executed flawlessly. There is a sense of constant panic and dread when you're exploring, particularly when you're short on resources or dust. You want to spend resources to improve your team, but want to save some for emergencies. If I have a complaint about the game is that it's a bit too easy. Once you understand the fundamentals of the game and have a good strategy, it pays to just keep repeating that strategy for the entire game. However, the developers very intelligently added a variety of ships that change the rules of the game. This is where the future challenge lies.One of the best titles in recent memory. Well worth the low price.

content:
Posted: May 3, 2015
												Dungeon of the Endless is a beautiful mash up of different genres that is really hard to identify.It is a rogue lite, tower defense, survival, resource management game with a bit of rpg thrown in, let me elaborate more.You begin the game after you choose your starting party of two people, these characters are the survivors of an attack at your ship near a mysterious planet. You choose a pod your heroes escaped in, which dramatically changes the rules of the dungeon, and off you go in your emergency landing, deep inside this strange complex. From there on, your only chance to escape the planet, is to carry your crystal from the damaged pod up to the surface. You have to use elevators to do this, they effectively mark the start and the end of each level. The game consists in exploring every floor searching for the exit, but also for resources, merchants, weapons, other survivors or who knows what your next objective might be. In the meantime, your dust reserve is used to power up the complex while you explore, because dark areas spawn monsters, and monsters have a nasty habit of wanting to break your crystal... so what do you do? You build minor modules to protect the path you carve in the complex, you build major modules to help you attain resources every door you open, you research new or upgraded versions of the modules you can build and onward to adventure. As for your heroes, every character has his set of skills, level up progression, statistics and possible equipment slots, which promotes customization and adaptability. The game has two levels of difficulties, one is doable, the other one is pretty tough.Of course the game has tons of replay value, everything being randomized except items, modules and heroes, every room and branching is randomized so there is no chance you will have the same game twice, even the merchants sell not only different stuff, but even accept a random resource for trade. The multiplayer is great but I suggest grabbing a friend since this a highly strategical game, more than an action one, but I've met my fair share of reasonable people online.If that wasn't enough, we are talking about the Endless lore, the same you find on Endless Space and Endless Legend, which is really cool if you're fan of the work Amplitude is doing, even the resources represent the FIDS system from the game (Food, Industry, Dust, Science).Overall I had a blast with this little title, I wasn't even expecting much but it became one of my favorite indie rogue like titles really fast. Not everyone appreciates it though (like one of my friends) though I still can't understand him, this game has everything one could ever hope for, it's original and cheap too!------------------------------------------EDIT : My nominee for The “Just 5 More Minutes” Award, since I always relax and sink in this more time than I realize.

content:
Posted: August 15, 2016
												A unique combination of roguelite, dungeon-crawler, and tower defense. Definitely worth a look. I love the graphics, and the music even more. If you own Endless Space and/or Endless Legend (Amplitude's other games), then it's worth it to buy the upgraded editions, as there's some unique content available by owning those other games. If you buy the upgraded editions of those games, you'll get added content for buying Dungeon of the Endless! None of it's essential, but some of it's fun.I've played over 50 hours of the game and have unlocked all but 1 character, and only half of the pods (the 'ship' you start in--various pods alter the starting conditions and change the rules throughout the course of the game). There's plenty of content, and the formula works well enough to provide hours of gameplay. For some real fun and chaos, just add friends! You can't pause in multiplayer, and with 4 players, everyone controls their own character, making coordination vital and extremely fun, especially if you can get some voice chat going (which is easy now that steam's voice chat is pretty damn good these days.)*One thing to be aware of: You do not directly control the actions of your characters, nor do you directly engage in combat! You click to open doors, interact with NPCs and objects, and move from room to room. The characters will automatically attack enemies based on certain priorities. You can activate your abilities on command, but that's it. When I bought it, I thought you controlled your characters like in Diablo or League of Legends or Dota, but that isn't the case and I was majorly turned off. But I quickly discovered that the more hands-off control lend itself very well to this game and quickly picked up on it and started having a blast!9.5/10, would recommend. I subtracted .5 only because there are a couple minor annoyances regarding controls: I wish you could assign all your heroes' abilities each their own keybind. As it is, you have to select that hero and then press a key (or click an icon) to activate the ability. It's fine in singleplayer when you can pause it, but in MP when you're controller 2-3 heroes at once, it can be a pain in real-time.

content:
Posted: December 12, 2013
Early Access Review
								Unlike a lot of "Early Access" games, v0.1.1 of Dungeon of The Endless feels like a relatively complete game.  It's stable and has a great mix of overall game mechanics that work well to produce a coherent game.  To try to describe this game in conventional terms might just confuse you.  Yes, it has aspects of roguelike games, real time strategy games, role playing games, tower defense games, and board games.  Personally, I think of it as mostly a board game with each "turn" divided into a time before you open another door, which will reveal treasure, a merchant, waves of enemies, blueprints, or something else - you never know!  Then it's a mad scramble reminiscent of a real time strategy/tower defensive hybrid to keep everything upright until the next turn.  When deciding who to level up or equip with gear, that's where the RPG aspect enters the picture.This board-game like mechanic can be a good thing because it introduces a lot of interesting choices.  If I assign my hero here, will they be able to make it back to where they need to be if enemies appear there?  Do I spend my industry points on producing more industry points, producing things I need, or do I try to scimp on points now so I have more avaialble to use on the next map?  Do I invest my dust in that great piece of equipment, or is it more important that I power rooms?  These choices are clever in that many of them are just comprimises; there's often not a "right" choice, just a good guess at what might work out in the long run.  I like a game that makes me think.  Yet, Endless Dungeon is rarely ever overwhelming, just rich with important choices to make and requiring you pay attention when your heroes are fighting so they don't get slain needlessly.  It's quite remarkable they consider this quite-playable product such an early version.  True, you're limited to just three (four?) random map levels per game (which you can exhaust in an hour), there's not yet skills on the heroes, the tech tree systems isn't in yet, and so on.  Yet, the game is more complete than many $15 titles I've bought.  Amplitude studios seems to know what they're doing, and if they call this version v0.1.x, then it's clear this game should be of staggering, epic proportions if they see their plans through to completion.

Early Access Review
								What a wonderful roguelike comboed with tower defense.  Even in Alpha this is as stable and playable as Endless Space was on release.  Amplitude had my trust after Endless Space which is why I risked an Alpha purchase.  Not disappointed.  You start with two heroes.  They have skills, inventory and slots of weapon/armour/tool.  Each room you clear gives you the next wave of resources which you can use to level your heroes, build or research.  You can have your heroes man stations that you build in each room to vary your resource income if you can do without them.  So you have to manage your heroes and incoming enemies.  That's the basics of it.

content:
Posted: January 4, 2015
												Pretty addictive. It's a fairly unique combination of genres - I'd call it primarly a resource management/tower defense game with roguelike elements and some RPG mixed in rather than a roguelike with TD elements, but that's just me.+ High replayability - unlockable ships (influences how you start as well as your strategy throughout) unlockable characters, randomized maps, loot and research opportunities makes each playthrough different.+ "One more turn/game" appeal - whether I was trying out a recent unlock or simply trying to correct the mistakes I made last game, I found myself wanting more.+ Challenging without being unfair, tactical without being overwhelming - this game can slap you into the dirt, but when you lose it tends to be because of your own actions rather than RNG. And while there are enough mechanics in play to make the game interesting and intense, you won't find yourself lost. You die, you do better. You die, you do better.+ Good sound/music. Not much else to say.- Ugly. If you're used to roguelikes you'll be expecting this, and if you're like me you'll get so immersed that you'll forget it's ugly entirely. But, when hordes of enemies are streaming in and you can only recognize a few distict shapes in the pack, you'll wish it was just a tad better. Still, very minor.

content:
Posted: November 3, 2014
												Dungeon of the Endless is a top-down roguelike dungeon exploration & tower defense game with many unlockable elements set in the Endless game universe.The player uses a squad of up to 4 characters to explore a multi-floor dungeon one room at a time while protecting a power crystal. Like other Endless games, the four resources are Food, Industry, Dust, and Science (FIDS). With each door opened, more FIDS accumulate, but dangerous monsters may spawn. Players eventually discover a dungeon floor exit and carry the crystal to a new dungeon floor, continuing on until the game ends at the 12th floor.Characters may be discovered in-game and unlocked after completing a certain number of floors with that character. Characters have different strengths as might be expected, including attack power, defense, movement speed, and "wit", which in this game translates into better module operation bonuses. Certain secret combinations of characters lead to different in-game events.Food, Industry, and Science increase in a predictable fashion with each door opened, but Dust is less predictable and cannot be saved between levels. Dust may sometimes be discovered in new rooms or obtained after defeating monsters.Rooms adjacent to the crystal may be powered (or "lit") subject to a limit based on the current amount of Dust. Lit rooms do not spawn monsters. Given enough industry, different "modules" may be built in a powered room based on the characteristics of that room--not every room can hold a module, no room can hold more than one "major module", and different rooms have different limits for "minor modules".Items may be discovered in new rooms and are bought and sold for FIDS at merchants which may be discovered in new rooms.A special Research module may appear in a new room, allowing for Science to be invested to unlock new modules or higher levels of existing modules.Modules may be removed, for example removing an unneeded Research module to make room.Like any great game, Dungeon of the Endless presents the player with many interesting choices, for example:- leave a room dark to spawn more monsters and the chance for more Dust, or light the room to reduce monster spawn and provide room for modules?- invest Industry in FIDS-producing modules (longer-term payoff) or defensive modules (immediate payoff)?- spend Food to recruit a new character, or save Food to see if a better choice is available later?- take the exit as soon as it is found, or open a few more doors to try to gain more Food, Industry, and Science for the next level?- invest Science now, or remove the Science module in favor of a different major module?Tactical elements include: positioning of characters when unlocking a door, character movement between rooms during combat, activation of special abilities, healing (which takes Food), and resetting abilities (which takes Science) in combat. Combat may be paused for easier micro-management, but some players will find it more fun to do without pausing (there's even a Steam Achievement for beating a dungeon without pausing).

Posted: January 4, 2015
												Pretty addictive. It's a fairly unique combination of genres - I'd call it primarly a resource management/tower defense game with roguelike elements and some RPG mixed in rather than a roguelike with TD elements, but that's just me.+ High replayability - unlockable ships (influences how you start as well as your strategy throughout) unlockable characters, randomized maps, loot and research opportunities makes each playthrough different.+ "One more turn/game" appeal - whether I was trying out a recent unlock or simply trying to correct the mistakes I made last game, I found myself wanting more.+ Challenging without being unfair, tactical without being overwhelming - this game can slap you into the dirt, but when you lose it tends to be because of your own actions rather than RNG. And while there are enough mechanics in play to make the game interesting and intense, you won't find yourself lost. You die, you do better. You die, you do better.+ Good sound/music. Not much else to say.- Ugly. If you're used to roguelikes you'll be expecting this, and if you're like me you'll get so immersed that you'll forget it's ugly entirely. But, when hordes of enemies are streaming in and you can only recognize a few distict shapes in the pack, you'll wish it was just a tad better. Still, very minor.

content:
Posted: April 25, 2014
Early Access Review
								Most people that enjoy FTL will enjoy this. In FTL the thrill is getting to the next beacon. Seeing what the game throws at you, and trying your best to handle itIn DoTE? What's behind the next door? If the proposition of sick anticipation for the next sadistic amalgam of chaos that you might find behind that door excites your inner masochist then this is the game for you!Dungeon of the Endless is an immaculate blend of genres---so much so that it feels like something brand new. The consortium of rpg elements, tower defense, procedurally generatred levels, and tower defense are all wrapped superbly in Amplitude's signature UI. Speaking of the UI it is sleek, clean, cripse, and effectively delivers you all the information required seemlessly. While the game is far from complete there is more than enough difficutly and challenge involved. A meaty roster of characters and several difficult floors to plow through. The randomly generated nature offers much replayability, all the while Amplitude contineously injects more content!

content:
Posted: December 2, 2015
												This game is hard, relentless, unforgiving, incredibly fun, addictive and has tons of replayability.  I personally think this game is a hard to learn, hard to master type game.  This game is not for the weak-willed who seek handholding, checkpoints or walks in the park.  Dungeon of the Endless is a tower defence game that draws RPG, rogue-like, dungeon crawling and resource management elements.  You start each game by picking 2 heroes out of a 24 (with all of DLC and unlockable characters) member cast.  Each hero has different stats that help your team in one way or another (Speed, Power, Health, and Wit).  Your objective is to look for the exit of the floor, which leads to the next floor.  Each floor gets progressively harder and harder the further down you go.  To "win" or complete the game, you have to complete all 12 floors.  You start each floor in a single room and have up to 4 different directions you can go.  Each room you enter has a chance to spawn dust (used to powers rooms) as well as: other resources, merchants, treasure (that can be worn for bonuses or sold for resources), other heroes to add to your team (for a max of 4 heroes per team) and/or monsters!  For each room you enter, any room you do not have powered by dust has a chance to spawn monsters in it.  You will eventually come to a point where the minority of your rooms will be powered and lots of monsters are spawning.  This is where strategy and micro-managing your heroes comes into play.  You have to find the perfect setup where you can defend all your modules and your crystal, without your heroes dying.  This will require quick thinking, quick calculations and quick action to make sure you can defend all directions without losing modules, heroes or resources.  If you lose (from either monsters taking your crystal down or losing all your heroes), you do not start from where you left off, you will need to start from floor one again with a new team.I’ve read a ton of negative reviews saying this game has way too much RNG to be recommended.  You can definitely be ♥♥♥♥ed over by RNG in this game, but 90% of the time you have that bad of RNG, it’s definitely winnable if you just play your heroes and defence right.  The feeling of conquering an insanely hard floor after getting some bad RNG is pure bliss.  I recommend this game to anyone looking for a challenging game or a completely new take on tower defence.  You will lose NUMEROUS times before you finally win (on Easy at least), but that first victory is one to remember.  If you’re looking to start playing this game, I’d highly recommend checking out the let’s play link below.  This video really helped me understand the basics when I was first starting out.  


YouTube™ Video: Let's Look At: Dungeon of the Endless 

			Views: 202,146		

			Dungeon of the Endless on Steam: http://store.steampowered.com/app/249050/ Dungeon of the Endless is a dungeon crawling roguelite with a fusion of strategy, RPG, and tower defense mechanics.

content:
Posted: December 16, 2013
Early Access Review
								This game just proves that you don't need a powerful graphic engine to make a potentially great game. The interface is intuitive and the style is rich enough to give you an artgasm. The game itself has a fairly easy objective - get your dust-filled crystal thing to an exit. But don't be fooled by the simplicity, the game can be punishing. When you take the crystal out of its notch, be prepared to face continous waves of enemies. It's difficult in a sense that it'll force you to utilize anything at your disposal in favor of just making a run for it. It's a game that will test your attention as well as your ability to make tough strategic choices.If you're sick and tired of shooters, consider picking up this game. It's colorful, easy to pick up and incredibly easy on the eyes.

content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
												As a recent release, I  have found this to be my favourite game so far this month, the gameplay is unique, and a good combination of genres.The music is wonderful, the characters are different and offer a variety of combinations of skills. The only negative thing I'd have to say about this game is the multiplayer, at times can be very unstable. If this is fixed in any coming updates I'd have no complaints about this game. The difficulty is just right, and rewarding and I can't wait to see if we get even more brutal difficulties to truly test our sanity and endurance. Some would say the dust generation is unbalanced, but I find it just right, of having to choose between fully exploring or just blizting it before i lose any (more) characters. To any of my friends who even reads this, you totally gotta get it for such a cheap game.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 5, 2014
												Loving this game so far. I have both Endless Space and Endless Legend, and I think they both show promise, but ultimately aren't quite 'there' yet. But with this game, they've taken the world, the lore, and the feel, as well as some of the concepts (resources) and applied them in a VERY different package. This is part RPG, part tower defence, all fun!Graphics style works, and the game has a feel that is reminiscent of the wonderful iPad game - Sword & Sworcery. Pixel graphics that really work, a wonderful, atmospheric soundtrack. Really solid.And the game play is wonderful (albeit hard - i'm playing on the easiest setting and still finding it a real challenge to get a decent strategy). You'll need to be a little patient, but use those defences and you'll get there. A wonderful example of how a simple concept, well executed, can be delightfully engaging. Well done dev team, well done!

												This game has a neat little combination of features that is kind of a mix of dungeon crawler and tower defense. It's fun to pick up and play for a bit or to try and get all the way through a run. The art is pixel, and when you see the more functional and attractive art of their other two games on offer here on Steam it makes you wonder why they chose to go with such a terrible look. I can live with that, I've always been a proponent of fun gameplay over shiny graphics.Unfortunately the multiplayer seems to be hampered by bugs. When a player quits out I am normally left locked out of the game. The game just doesn't hold enough appeal for me to attempt ot grind away in single player. For this reason alone I can't recomend the game. I have finished only about half of my attempts at multiplayer, and that's probably only becaused I died so early on it didn't have a chance to glitch out on me.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
												Very enjoyable roguelike with tower defense elements. Enough tower/hero types to keep you engaged for more than one playthrough. More difficulty options would be great, as "Too Easy" is exactly what is implied, while "Easy" can be pretty brutal at times. The option for 4 player coop is great, although the coop mode requires a bit of polish before I would recommend it. Coop has no ability to save your game, and with a full playthrough requiring a few hours of gameplay, you better make sure you set aside some time. I recommend playing at least a game or two on singleplayer, as this will allow you to unlock some characters before trying multiplayer. Also, the game had a few connectivity problems where players lost connection with each other about an hour in (In our case, two players maintained connection, while two players lost connection, while still able to view each other's movement. Some sort of host desynch...)Overall, worth the $13.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2016
												The title is wrong, as these dungeons are not endless. Unless play it in endless mode... Yeah.Well, it's a roguelike rpg dungeon crawler with tower-defense elements. You crash into some shiттy place and you got this cristal, right? Well, you need to carry that cristal all the way to the elevator, which you have to find in a first place, as you have no way of knowing what will expect you in the next door. Maybe it's loot room, maybe it's full of enemies, maybe there is another character inside that you can recruit for your group, maybe I'll go and fцск myself... You just don't know. And thats the fun part of this game. Get your group, explore the dungeon and try to get to the end. I suggest to reinforce your path to the elevator with turrets of all sorts, as things will get really bad really fast once you remove the cristal from the previous spot. This game has a good price-replayability ratio and it's a wise purchase, if you are a fan of roguelike games or tower defense ones. Fun to play it in coop with your friends too. I give it 8 of 10 and now I am going to cry myself to sleep. Have a nice day, anonymous reader.

number of helpful: 6 of 10 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 31, 2016
												Before buying this game, keep in mind that, unlike what you might think from the description, this is not a very complex rogue-like. While there are elements of tower defense, resource management, and levelled characters, there is little learning curve, meaningful decisions, or stat mongering in the game.In short, it's much closer to a mobile game for PC than it is to NetHack. Which is absolutely fine, just something to keep in mind before purchasing.POSITIVES:- Immediately accessible from the first level- Meaningful replayability via different starting conditions and Endless Mode- Enjoyable world characterization - Crisp assembly- FunSOMEWHAT NEGATIVES:- Fairly easy. I beat the hardest starting difficulty in three tries, and each scenario in one or two- RPG elements are a little dull- Individual levels often end anti-climatically- Exploration lacks variety- No voice actingBOTTOME LINE:This is a great little game that's perfect for killing idle hours. If the description intrigues you, it delivers. (But just don't expect a game of great depth.) A sequal would be fantastic.---PLEASE NOTE BEFORE PLAYING:This game comes with a free DLC that adds four Team Fortress characters to the game. This is pretty fun when you're used to the game, but it ruins the atmosphere to run across a Heavy or Pyro during your first couple playthroughs. I'd reccommend unchecking the DLC box on the game's page in your library before launching, and turning it on after a couple hours to see if you like it.

number of helpful: 7 of 12 people (58%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 30, 2015
												This is an amazing game.I've put over a hundred hours in so far, and there's no end in sight. I CANNOT RECOMMEND THIS GAME HIGHLY ENOUGH!!! It's still being supported and actively expanded by the developer, which is always nice. The latest expansion pack with the Rescue Team is still a mystery to me. I haven't explored all the content, or discovered the storyline reasons for each character's presence. But I expect good, high quality content, which is what I've received with this game so far.My only issue with this game is that it's STILL buggy as hell. It WILL regularly crash on you and/or devour your saves and leave you with only a fading memory of those 11 floors you and your buddy put in on Easy mode, escaping death by a fingernail's breadth. Then *POOF* the game takes a crap on you. This WILL happen. I personally think the game is worth putting up with this stuff, but I can see why it would put some people off. All this being said, this game has many hours of fun dungeon delving for you to enjoy. The randomization is sometimes cruel, but overall the game is reasonably well balanced. Some characters are quantitatively better than others, pure and simple. But there's enough variation in the character skills to make trying each one out something you'll want to try. Especially with the expansion content, there's significantly altered mechanics.Finally, PLEASE play this game in multiplayer a couple times. It's a fantastic experience that you won't forget. You and up to 3 friends will be pitted against the dungeon together, which is what friends are all about. When you do this, I recommend that you learn how to manually back up your own saves. It's just too painful to lose a game to a corrupt save, or a de-sync glitch, or any number of other things. Just don't use it to cheat, please.This game is one of my top five favorite plays right now. I recommend you try it too!

content:
Posted: October 19, 2015
												Fun, simple, but very hard dungeon exploration/survival/tower defense game. You have maxium of 4 heroes that explore dungeon level by level, trying to find elevator to the next level. Dungeon is built out of rooms, and uou open up doors which represent turns. Each turn you gain resources that you use to build modules and towers, research new things, level up and heal heroes. While exploring, you encounter hordes of monsters spawning out of darkness, which will try to kill you and your core, which you need to protect to get out of the dungeon.Like all Endless games, this game as well is meant to be replayed again and again, with different settings, like characters or core-mechanics that you unlock by playing the game.For a casual scrub like me, the game is definitely too hard on easy difficulty, but challenging enough on "Too Easy" difficulty.Even though I haven't been able to beat the game on easy difficulty, I recommend it. It looks good, it sounds good, and it's fun to play. There is also multiplayer which is big bonus for a co-op fan like me!

number of helpful: 8 of 14 people (57%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 31, 2015
												It's time to toss in my two cents.At first I was like - Dungeon of the Endless gets me some free stuff for other games I own from Amplitude Studios, and I get to support them. Cool.Then I played it and lost a lot. I suck at Rogue-like games. So I put it away.A few months pass, and a Steam friend of mine invites me to play with him via MP (he's in France). 5 hours later, and I see the allure, but I still suck in SP. SO, DotE gets shelved again. A few more months pass and I need to write a Friday eXcurision for eXplorminate and here is the product (http://explorminate.net/2015/09/11/friday-excursion-dungeon-of-the-endless/). That results in me playing the iPAD version, and I finally learn how to play the game.So, how is the game? FUN. But it's hard, and brutal, but if you plan ahead and prepare, you can do fine on the Very Easy level, which is actually normal to hard. Easy is anything but, and don't get me started on the hard mode (you need a special pod for that). On to the review!!!You start the game as a survivor of a crashed escape pod on Auriga where the Endless were conducting experiemnts on live subjects in a crazy torture lab/arena. THe planet is like Mortal Kombat world and this is where the combatants are made.  Anyways, as you try to escape the labs to the surface, you face monsters and random events every time you open a door...  Why do you open doors? to search for the escape elevator. Each time you open the door, you get resources that you can use to upgrade your heroes, power and buildup your rooms, and investigate tech to further your modules.You repeat the above for 12 floors until you find the exit, and all the while, you'll be attacked by hordes of monsters.Let me repeat this point - the game is BRUTAL in SP, and equally BRUTAL in MP, but at least there, you get to lose together with your friends.I recommend this title, because it fantastic, and Amplitude Studios has just released a 3rd, that's right, count it.  1.. 2... 3... free dlc adding content.Have fun dying, I know I did.

number of helpful: 48 of 93 people (52%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 30, 2014
Early Access Review
								Fantastic art direction - mediocre gameplay.A game that (currently) isn't the sum of its parts. All the elements are there, apart from something compelling to do when you play it. The concept is original enough, but the execution is in turns tedious, repetitive and unfair. Playing simply involves repeating the same actions, stage after stage, and hoping the RNG doesn't screw you too badly.Unlike true Rogue-likes such as FTL and Binding of Isaac, this is essentially a very pretty, but basic, tower defence game with occasional difficulty spikes, or loot drops, as its 'random' element. None of these are compelling like Spelunky's altars or shopkeepers, or FTL's story choices, but simple occasional resource gifts or monster waves.The problem here is that it misjudges what makes tower defence fun - accurately managing those resources. By tying those into the RNG (level layout strongly dictates your defences and resource gathering) your strategy is always a slave to the RNG, and can often be ruined simply by an obnoxious layout simply starving you of resources, or forcing you to defend more points than is possible.This makes the game a case of going through the motions, repeating an optimal strategy with little breathing room for experimentation, until you luck into a good run or are forced into an unfair loss. All 10 stages play exactly the same, but just get larger and contain more damaging enemies. Once you've finished stage 1, you've essentially seen the entire game.A shame, as every other element is dripping with style and polish, and the mixture of TD, dungeon crawling and Rouge-like works as a proof of concept, but unfortunately all you get here is simply a marriage of extremely shallow reprentations of all three genres.6/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
Early Access Review
								With out a doubt one of the best games that I purchased this year.  It's a rogue-like and it can be hard and unforgiving at time but that makes it all the more sadistically fun.  The RPG elements including character leveling, equipment, and individual abilities unique to each hero, mesh well and ensures multiple playthroughs which can be very unique depending on which heros the player is using.  As your heros open doors of the dungeon they accumulate resouces which are used to build offencive and defensive turrets in rooms,  power rooms and constructed turrets or generators in rooms,  to level characters and to purchase turret and character upgrades and equipment.   The combination of managing all these elements might first sound complex  but the game does a great job at intragating all the features togather well in a way that makes sense and also makes you think tactically the further you get in the dungeon.    Though the game is stll in development  it  has been updated regularly in the six or so months that I have owned it and alot of new content has been added.  At my last playthrough there were eight levels to the dungeon implemented and over ten heros (though I have only unlocked 5 or so) with more being planned as the game is updated and gets closer to offical release.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 18, 2013
Early Access Review
								The core ideas behind Dungeon of the Endless are on the right track and the promise of content to come should turn this into a masterpiece.The curent look and feel of this alpha indicate a high level of care in the game's development - this is a surprisngly polished release and is very much playable (and re-playable). What I really liked:- The graphics are great (and I'm not a pixel graphics fanboy) - The dungeon generation has been unique and fairly unpredictable each time I re-rolled.- The heroes are well individualized and you need to adapt your strategy to accomodate their strenghts and weaknesses.- The gameplay can be challenging and unforgiving however it doesn't feel frustrating.- I haven't come accross any obvious 'spam this item to win' holes.- The 'chance' factor works really well with what the game tries to achieve and it forces you to re-think your strategy.- There's no redundant micromanagement of heroes.- No redundant micropositioning of turrets either.- Mobs aren't ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.- No game-crippling bugs that I have encountered (and for an alpha this fresh, that's really surprising)- Game has potential to become virtually endless in terms of replayability (assuming things go well dev wise).What I didn't really like:- Some turrets aren't really useful enough, or rather can be happily ignored throughout the entire game without you missing their utility. I'm referring specifically to the turrets that grant hero bonuses to armor, strength, or heal the hero.- When the world becomes larger it can get quite tedious to manage heroes on oposite sides of the map. Perhaps a minimap might be useful.- Switching between heroes can get a bit wonky and it's not always terribly obvious which one you're controling.- The 'you found the door, there it is!!!!!' pointers are insanely annoying. The obvious:- Currently not a whole lot of content is available - early alpha.- Game won't be for everyone and you might hate it.All in all, I really like this game and hope it manages to accomplish what it set out to do without needing to get dumbed down or glittered up.

content:

Early Access Review
								If I could think of a game like this, I would say FTL...Of the little time i've played, its pretty fun right now.Just, really, really random so its hard to expect anything.What you do is search a dungeon for the exit, protect your crystal, and bring it to the exit.The thing is, when you explore a room, a random event may occur, like npcs, shops, or enemy encounters.In order to protect ya crystal, you gotta power rooms up with the crystal's energy (Which can some get gained by fighting. In rooms you farm resources, set up defenses, etc.But the "Time" based method in generating things and researching is by the doors you open.So once you open all of the doors, your somewhat dead and have to wait for waves of enemies to spawn.Also when your carrying your crystal, the rooms you have powered turn off slowly.But, if any doubt, try FTL. The game play is pretty similar.Overall, Great game, that needs more developement but is great at this state for tactical-ish turn based stuffz

												I never predicted the fact that Roguelike and Tower Defense genres could go so well together. DotE is extremely addictive and fun for fans of those genres, it takes some of the best elements of both along with a really visually appealing take on retro pixel art. The only glaring flaws are the inability to save your game during multiplayer, and numerous current bugs involving loading and desynch in multiplayer. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 4, 2015
												An endless journey from the depths of un-knowing cluster♥♥♥♥, to the peaks of 500-industry-a-floor victory. Dungeon of the Endless may fulfill a multitude of gaming genres, but in my opinion, it satisfies most in the learning curve, and the utter feeling of good, earned, whole-hearted progress. Your first time through will see you lose a few runs, then manage to get to level 11, then finally complete the game on Too Easy, patting yourself on the back thoroughly, having unlocked a few achievements. Are you finished? Alas, you are not. You look at your character list;"♥♥♥♥in L m8 so many damn characters tah ♥♥♥♥in jack around wit"And then you notice how badass Hakenshi looks, and then you realize how broken Lady Jolari is, and you see all of the ships and achievements you can unlock, and you're like;"Hot diggity doggy I'mma get me some achievements"So you end up spending a full day playing multiplayer, leaving your friends behind on floors for ♥♥♥♥♥ and giggles, until finally, at last, you finish a run on the Medbay, because no one knows how to manage food resources. I came here for the pixel art and the soundtrack, both of which are absolutely marvelous. The gameplay in singleplayer far exceeds the multiplayer; the amount of control and strategy you'll slowly learn to control is incredibly rewarding; your first playthrough will have floor clears of around 15 minutes each, but by the time you get going, you can finish them in under 2 minutes (I've managed to get 59 seconds in a multiplayer Floor 3). 10/10 Graphics10/10 Audio10/10 Expectations10/10 Singleplayer8/10 Multiplayer (poorly optimized for shared resources, but not a huge issue)baller amount of characters yo and the DLC is ripe for pickin, though, Crystal Edition is a little pricey for what you get.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 9, 2015
												This game is absolutely amazing.When I first got it, I hopped straight into a game with my friend (who also just bought it) and a random. I struggled to understand the game at first, but after 10 minutes I was hooked. I soon after played through quite a few times with my friend, causing the death of many heroes, and countless failures. But after my first successful run on "Too easy" I was extremely  proud. Two hours of epic battles, narrow escapes, and many lost heroes (let the tears flow) lead to a well earned victory. Several months later, I picked it up again solo. It's a different game solo. Although I feel the gameplay is much better solo, it's hard to learn from your mistakes. This game requires a lot of strategy, and I made the same poor choices over and over again. However, once I was finally able to learn from them and make my way through my first "easy" clear, it all paid off.This game is increadibly inspiring. The art style, along with the music, setting, and the "all is lost feeling" really get you into it. I find myself picking the heros that have cool stories, and look awesome over the heroes which I probably should pick to support my team. I love the lore connections and dialogs made for the characters. Everything in this game is unique, from the enimies to the merchant, to the rooms, and the maps. Sometimes I'll spend a little extra time sitting in the main menu, because I love the song that plays.Overall, I would say this is a game worth buying. It's a fantastic single player game, and pretty fun co-op aswell. It is, however, a little more expensive, but I feel like it's definately worth it. It's like buying a piece of art, that's also a great game. Looking forward to seeing more titles or DLC in the future.-Pooks

content:
Posted: November 10, 2015
												Take FTL style micro and put it into a rogue-lite (or rogue-like or whatever you want to call it,) game with tower defense elements and you get Dungeon of the Endless. Pick two heroes and a game modifier (the type of pod you crash into the dungeon in) and you can recruit an additional two heroes for a maximum of four (if your original two survive) characters with special powers that can level up and equip with items. You get resources by building generators for Industry, Science, and Food and protect them with a host of 'modules' you research throughout a dungeon. (and personal interactions in single player depending if you have two specific characters.) I bought the game on sale and the multiplayer was broken for about 3 weeks until they released a new update but now it seems to be working well for most people. So I guess keep in mind the game studio developing this game is busy with all the other games they are working on at the same time, multiplayer tends to still have an occasional bug. The multiplayer is fun but you need good communication at the end to succeed. Also if you happen to play the game please know this game seems to be taking the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of FTL by stepping up their naming of difficulties - there are two; "Too Easy" and "Easy." don't be ashamed at ALL to play on too easy, especially if you're on multiplayer with new people. (up to 4 people - one for each hero)

content:
Posted: December 15, 2013
Early Access Review
								(As of 0.1.1)It’s tough, and probably needs a little rebalancing as to where things spawn and how much, but being it's in alpha I'm extremely impressed. I made it through on my 5th or 6th try, at least as far as the early access would allow (level 4 I think?). I can tell I'm going to love this game though. The two negative things I have to say about it are that occasionally it'll seem a bit unfair and loot will only rarely spawn that you can use if you don’t have a diverse team (something you can't choose). Once I started a new game died after I opened the third door. There was nothing that I could have done to prevent this and was a clear case of the game killing me instead of me dying. Many times, starting out, you'll find that any gear you stumble across is only good to be sold since neither of your two people can use a pistol, for example  (despite one of them being able to use machine guns...?). Whether the latter issue is problem with the loot drops or the gear system is subjective I suppose.All that being said though, I love this game so far. I love the genre bending mechanics and the not-quite-shadowrun and not-quite-fallout world. I love the art and sound. I love the droplets of story you get with each random party and each piece of gear you stumble across. I cannot recommend this game enough.

content:
Posted: April 17, 2015
												Dungeon of the Endless has brought me back to my gaming roots from the early 90s, yet pulled me through a world of fresh new elements I haven't quite expreience fully.First, you crash land on a planet, and are plunged deep into the dungeon. You find yourself in a room with one other and a crystal. As you manage your way through the first floor you encounter monsters of various traits, merchants with certain goods, and science machines to advance yourself. Leveling up is achieved through the gaining of the food resource, and you can manufacture food, and 2 others. Once your reach the exit, you must bring your crystal with you and be challenged by al the monsters of the floor.I find after a few play throughs that DotE is a perfect game. Nothing more needs to be added to this little masterpiece, and nothing needs to be taken away. Well balanced, well designed, and a tough play, like games used to be!I challenge anyone new to this game to attempt to take this game on on easy mode.  Be prepared a force feeding of humility!!!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
Early Access Review
								Here's my elevator pitch for Dungeon of Endless:"It's a rogue-like, tower defense game with Left 4 Dead finales thrown in."And it truly is an amagame of these things. It's like an rogue-like RPG in that you're exploring a randomly-generated dungeon and dealing with the enemies and other things you encounter there.The tower-defense element pulls heavily from real-time strategy and role-playing elements. There's a pretty meaty three-resource system that you engage. You build machines to generate more of the resources then use those resources to build all kinds of offensive and defensive weapons or to level up your heroes (each with their own unqiue attributes, powers and weapons to equip). Every time you open a door in the dungeon your machines produce the goods. There's also a chance of enemy waves spawning -- that's where the tower defense comes in. You need to build defenses to prevent them from running roughshod over your stuff (and eventually destroying your precious energy crystal). Smart, strategic exploration plays a big role here, creating choke points and making sure that enemies don't swarm you all at once is key to survival.Once you find the exit to the dungeon floor there's a final event where you must manually carry your power crystal from the start of the dungeon to the exit -- all the while fending off enemy's. That's where the Left 4 Dead allusion comes into play. These final runs can go horribly if you haven't powered and defended the path. Since I've been playing there's been constant adjustment to the economy and difficulty of the game -- this is the kind of fine tuning you want from a game that's in Alpha. But throughout I've had fun playing the game. Even when the tuning made the game insanely hard. Even when the game is broken Dungeon of Endless is fun.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 23, 2014
Early Access Review
								TL;DR Great game, devoted devs, buy now if you want to shape the game and experience the development.As of 0.6.1 i am enjoying this game thoroughly. There are enough characters and since adding 8 levels an indepth clear is currently around 3 hours of play. Though i have read aot of complaints and they fall into two categories too hard or no diversity. In respect to difficulty there are currently two options, easy and too easy. As their name suggests  neither option is very difficult. However if you play this game and do not consider that is a combinations of many game types and aproach it as one you will lose fairly quickly. Also, aproaching each level with no forethought or strategy will cause a loss aswell. It is of course a strategy game so those who lack it will not suceed. Furthermore, the learning curve is fairly easy and once you get the hang of it is a blast.In respect to a lack of diversity you have to remember this game is still in alpha. if you are buying a early access game looking for a full game experience then you will be dissapointed. The devs are pushing out consistent updates, much faster than alot of the other early access games on steam. They fix bugs very quickly and if a patch is game breaking they pull it so you can still play while they work on it. By buying the game now you can shape development by voting on their website.The game itself is quite simple. There are currently 3 resources industry, science and food. Industry is for building modules and major modules help produce those three resources. Minor modules are turrets support turrets and defensive turrets. Science allows you to resource upgrades for your modules and new modules themselves. food allows you to recruit new heroes after your starting heroes, level up your heores(current max lvl 8 due to 8 Floors) and heal them during fights.You use these resources to build a defense network so that when the exit of the lvl is found you can safely bring your crystal(the object that allows you to power rooms so you can build in them) to the next lvl. Each level gets increasingly difficult with new enemies and more rooms.Heroes: Heroes come in all shapes in sizes and currently there are four stats, and five weapons types(currently 0.6.1). Stats are health,speed,damage and wit. Weapon types are sword, spear, pistol, machine gun, unarmed. health is how much life you start with and how much life you get every time you level up. Speed is movement speed. Wit is comparable to an intelligence stat but is mostly used for heroes you can operate major modules(Operating is to give a bonus to their production rate or bonus it gives) by increasing the operator bonus. Damage is the amount of damage you do. All of these stats scale when you level the heroe and different heroes are more proficient in different stats.There is no heroe that is useless all of them serve a specific purpose and you can win by using any combination of them.Also, there are armors and support items, most with comical names or premises. Finally a great amount of thought has gone into this game from the item descriptions and the heroe backgrounds to the strategies that are available and to the details in each room. This ia a great product and i am highly anticipating the finished version.

(Personal valuation 8/10)I must say this game may be an Alpha Version still - but it plays itself like a Full game.Random generated Maps and diffrent Characters each time make this game a great game to play when you are bored.But its not an easy one.The goal in this game is to bring your Energy-Crystal to the escape point, which will make you reach the next level - and thereby map of the game.Sounds easy? Wrong. The rooms you walk trough with your two start characters contain treasures, supplies or evil monsters which try to destroy your Crystal.Your Crystal can power rooms so no enemies spawn inside and so you can build defenses or generators. Every few rooms, some enemies spawn in dark rooms to attack your crystal.Will you find the exit and carry the crystal there, or will your enemies destroy you and your crystal?

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 25, 2014
Early Access Review
								After crashing on an unknown planet, Nurse Deena Ratchet and genetically engineered warrior Hikensha began working their way through the ship to hope for an escape. Along the way they recruited a young burglar named Golgy Phurtiver who, incidentally, thinks she's a spider of some sort. Things were going relatively well - Nurse Ratchet discovered a woman in stasis, who was revealed to be a bounty hunter named Sara Numas. They did not know that they were effectively recruiting Hikensha's replacement, however, who died tried to defend another survivor from the alien natives. The party marched upwards, exploring for every resource they could. Another survivor was revived from stasis, but the mercenary (who dubbed himself "Butcher") was eviscerated by what can only presumed to be giant mutant slugs when making casual conversation with a merchant. The three survivors, Deena, Golgy and Sara saved the merchant from the rampaging aliens, and quickly cleaned him out of his wares in exchange for the Dust they were using to power their various defenses, just before they moved on up to a new level of what was beginning to feel like a dungeon. For real though, Dungeon of the Endless does a lot of things right for a... roguelike, resource management 4X, RPG, platypus of a game. And as they're apparently working on multiplayer, I could see this becoming a Thing.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 3, 2015
												This game is the absolute perfect mix of Tower Defense, Strategy, and RPG, all mixed in with a bit of Beautiful Pixelated Graphics. The Gameplay is Smooth and Entertaining, Resource Management between you and your team is challenging, and Behind every door is the possibility of Life or Death.  This game could easily be played for hours with you and your 3 friends all shuffling around the rooms trying to not Screw up. In this game Teamwork and Communication is crutial and makes the game Entertaining. While you can play Single Player, I highly suggest buying this for you and a friend to play, it is about 10 times more fun with other people.  You have your 4 Resources, Food, Production (Which allows Building Defenses and Production Buildings), Science, And Dust.  Food Allows you to level up, buy items from vendors, heal in the middle of a turn, and even to hire new characters.  Science allows you to Research New Buildings and Building Upgrades, and also to occasionally buy items from vendors although it's more likely to see a vendor buying either Production or Food, And Dust allows you to power rooms for Defenses, Production, and (Most importantly) to stop Monsters from Spawning in a room. The Monsters are pretty Tough to say the least and can make you almost smash your keyboard into the wall which makes resource and power management more crucial to your sanity. To get through a Level you must find the exit and get both your Main Gem and your characters into the Exit Room. This game is Worth the Money and the developers are amazing for this game. If you have the money pick up a few copies for you and your friends

Posted: April 23, 2015
												This is a game that tries to mix some unusual set of mechanics into one game. I used to play this during early access and I could see the potential back then but it was far from balanced; it had one particular winning strategy that rendered most of the mechanisms in the game pointless.I'm happy to say that these days are long gone, the final version of Dungeon of the Endless is a very successful experimentation in game design that will keep you entertained exploring different strategies you never thought you'd use together in the same game.There's a lot of luck involved though, keep that in mind if that's not your thing. But luck is a factor in many games considered good, specially in rogue-likes. In these games the fun is like a good game of cards, you develop skills as you play the game over and over again until you know the best strategies for the hand you were given. And there are many cards and possibilities in Dungeon of the Endless. I totally recommend it.

content:
Posted: June 8, 2014
Early Access Review
								Dungeon of the Endless. Man, what can I say about this game? This game by far one of the most addidcting games in my game library, BY FAR. First to begin, this game is early access, yet there are slim to none bugs that I have come across. This game is a rogue-like dungeon crawler game, which means, if you die, prepare to throw something at the wall. DotE has an astounding amount of features, for being in ALPHA. This game hasn't even made it into beta yet, and look at all the features it currently has. Now you may be debating on which pack of DotE you should buy, and you may be considering buying the Founder Pack, and if you are, then go for it. Firstly, look at the features they are promising you upon release with the Founder Pack. Secondly, you gain access to the G2G voting system on Amplitude's website (this voting system is to choose what should be put in the game next) and ultimately decides the outcome of the game upon full release. And on an end note, you get to be apart and amazing community. BUY THIS GAME!

Early Access Review
								Its amazing. The levels are never the same , so you dont know if your find the door in the next room or 15 doors later.Its tower defense, and a rts at the same time. you open a room, put power to it, build a node, the make a guy work on it for more resources. then u fill the room up with towers of different sorts. sending the other guys to open the next room to fight the monsters, then retreat to your friend at the node to stand off all the monsters that come from the dark rooms you didnt power.you can only unlock a hero if you meet them, recruit them and keep them alive for 3 floors, or complete the dungeon, making the game worth going back to, to unlock them all.you never get angry when you get killed you just start again.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is very simple in its design but is incredibly well thought out in its execution. Randomly generated dungeons, resource management, multiple player characters, there is an incredible amount of depth and tactical feel to this game. The graphics and soundtrack make for a rather nostalgic feel instead of being outdated or lacking in their preformance they throw us back to old school titles that we used to know and love. This game feels like the developers are taking their time slowly but surely perfecting it, a nice change of pace from the games of today. Indie developers seem to have what big game companies have lost they are putting their heart and souls into this project and it shows Dungeon is an incredible game even in its alpha stages it has amazing potential. Those of you who bought the founders packs or might have helped kickstart it i feel like your faith will not go unrewarded. I only hope that future versions of the game might include harder difficulties, and maybe some lines of dialouge between heroes nothing voiced mind you but a few texts expressing the characters state of mind feelings towards one another or just jokes or comments about the dungeons themselves would be interesting, expanding the lore might also be cool finding codexes or data logs strewn about that contain information on the creatures crew ship and planet would be a fun treat for people who love to immerse themselves into the game. Though changes like that would be nice the game already offers so much in its alpha stage that i only imagine the completed product will be nothing less than amazing I give the alpha version of this game a 9/10 and I would say that this is my most anticapated title pending release and i absolutley can't wait for the final version I recomend anyone who reads this grab the founders pack as soon as possible you will not be dissapointed.

Maybe this and FTL have a secret hold on me. When it comes down to what you like about them, the challenge or the exploration, I think I like this game better as the challenge doesn't rely entirely on totallyrandom generation. Imagine if you could improve your ship in FTL without needingit all to come from shops or random encounters, but also gave you the options of directly influencing the parts of your ship with scrap, reinforcing the hull or weapons by themselves. That's what the heroesin this game fillthe gap on. Mixing it with tower defense makes this game engaging as you try tokeep heroes inbetween monsters and your crystal ala Dungeon Defenders, and executes it with the power sent to each grid. Managing these, your heroes and your defense network makes the game engaging.I would like to see more ships added. I enjoythe fact you can have certain gains and deficits granted by each pod, but if the developer doesn't make some whacky options available, or powerful ones, then the gimmick is short lived. I may be the only one who wants to see strange and fantastic options anymore, though. The excitement of seeing the doors open (as this is a door opening simulator, not a monster defense game as one would assume) is sadly reduced once you've run the gambit of monsters. I would like to see more happen.Gameplay: 9/10 Polished, well executed, and lacking in only the slightest of refinements. The stats lack descriptions and the tutorial hucks you in after a basic example.Story: 7/10 Must unlockthe characters and have them gab at one another for the story, but then again, that isn't what you came to do in this game, was it?Graphics: 8/10 Very pretty in game environments, monsters are varied but fit thesame subcategories, heroes continue to surpirse me in some ways. But the lit rooms sometimes offer little more than the dark ones did other than lack of gnawing death.Sound 9/10: As with games of this nature, sound effects are re-used oftenbut it doesn't grate the ears. Music is appropriate, well done, and generally pleasing.Overall: 9/10: Would open more doors.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 13, 2013
Early Access Review
								One more door. Just one more door.I am not a huge fan of tower defense games, but this little rogue-like has me hooked. Beyond the simple build-and-defend mechanic at the heart of every TD, DotE adds a compelling risk-reward element in the choice between doubling down and heading to the exit with the resources you've collected, or opening one more door in hopes of finding treasure or an ally at the risk of multiple waves of enemies threatening to destroy everything you have built. Striking that balance is key to your survival.Dungeon of the Endless is still in its early stages, but this little monster has a lot of potential. More items, more enemies, more levels, more non-combat encounters, story elements, heroic side quests, and party management mechanics are sure to come, but I would love to see competing parties of survivors taking resources (multiplayer plix?), the ability to relock doors (albeit either as limited use item or heroic ability), and different environments (with more incredible music added to what is already a killer soundtrack).I cannot wait to see how this game develops. I am officially pumped.

												I really enjoy this game, the art style is beautiful and the gameplay hooks you in but i think the singleplayer is hard to manage. I think that the pixelated top down format works well for managing all your heroes when trying to survive the hordes of monsters swarming from unpowered rooms. The building and research systems keep you on your toes when an example would be you are forced to choose whether to buy more prods to keep away badies or get an industry generator to help you later on. The only thing that I have managed to dislike about this game is the single player, trying to order around 2-4 heroes on your own while building defense turrets, healing the heroes,and using their power ups can get overwhelming and complicated especially if you are not used to the controls. Overall this game is a brilliant game with an amazing art style, great upgrading and building systems. even though the single player is hard to manage it is fun getting frustrated at Dungeon of the Endless.

												Configure your troops, allocate your dust, build modules, and then open a door.  Sounds simple, but there are greedier and less greedy configurations. Early Access Review
								Well I had my first taste of it, I think this game is really fun. I was wanting a Tower Defense type of game...but wanted to find something that had other elements if possible. Well I randomly came across this and I liked the art style instantly...Few games actually interest me with the oldish pixel style but this sure did. Its pretty fun overall, my first playthrough I expected to get killed while learning the game but it is EXTREMELY easy to pick up and play instantly. I made it from start to exit and fully explored the first 3 levels and finally parished on level 4 as waves got quite a bit larger. Its fun, its not too easy or too hard. Theres items, abilities, and the ability to level up and heal your heros. Theres artifacts to research more tech which I love, theres multiple different resources to take advantage of in multiple ways...its just a fun game. So far I cant say too much bad about this title as I was craving a certain game, I saw this and got more than expected..nothing more, nothing less. Very Fun, and im happy this is only in Alpha, the good can only get better from here. I recommend this game if it is below $10 any day. gameplay, graphics(if the style appeals to you and it does to me), and randomly generated dungeons for extra replay value that could be limitless depending how much you like the game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 21, 2014
												This clever, nicely-paced game isn't quite FTL, but it's worth mentiong in the same sentence. FTL's basic gameplay is quite repetitive, but there are interesting choices to be made at the strategic level, as you find out what modules are on offer.  DOTE's basic gameplay has a fair amount of variation, but the number of viable strategies feels a lot more limited.  There's definitely a real learning curve, and unlocking character stories is quite satisfying.  However, DOTE feels much more like a series of tactical and operational puzzles than it gives a feeling of strategy.  I may be saying that because I haven't worked out the tactical puzzles yet (and am therefore blind to strategy) but there's a strong feeling of 'starting again' with each new floor that drains my sense of satisfaction and progression.If you like exploring mazes and unlocking things, you'll get a ton of enjoyment out of DOTE.  That's not quite my thing, but I still enjoyed it for quite a few hours.

content:
Posted: February 13, 2015
												An engrossing adventure that I can't put down.  Each turn is a combination of excitement and dread as another door is opened.  Guide your chosen heroes to their gruesome death again and again.  Just when it feel like it's getting easier and you have control of the situation, the RNG gods will test your defenses and most of the time crush them.  Do you make the risky play or the safe one?  Horde resources and build stronger defenses?  Make a run for the end of the level or open another door in search of resources?  Beautifully polished with endearing graphics and captivating music.  Oozing character and dark humour.  HIGHLY recommended.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 17, 2014
Early Access Review
								There isn't much that hasn't already been said about this game. It really is as good as it sounds. And it is amazingly addictive; be prepared to find yourself sucked in for hours at a time if you're a fan of tower defense or strategy games in general. I've never been big on the tower defense formula for its own sake, but DotE sold me on the idea that tower defense can be fun. Of course, DotE offers much more than just tower defense; it introduces an economy-like system--if you've ever played a 4x strategy game, the system will look pretty familiar--that ties in with the tower defense setup (among other things) and at the same time rewards you for exploration and taking calculated risks, which is what the game is really about. On top of that, the game gives you a specific resource that can be used to power unlocked rooms and the defenses and production modules you've built in them but also doubles as currency; deciding to use it for currency instead of power always has consequences. If you like a challenge--the kind that requires a brain--Dungeon of the Endless will hook you pretty fast.The RPG elements add a surprising amount of depth to gameplay. You may not fall in love with any of the characters that make up your party, but you WILL be dismayed when you lose one, especially if you've spent any amount of time getting them kitted up--aside from the sinking realization that you now have one less defender. With different skillsets and weapon types, recruiting and keeping characters alive is an investment in your team-building strategy as different characters can complement each other in different ways (melee with ranged, for instance) and can also be put to work boosting specific segments of your economy to differing degrees depending on a proficiency statistic. Future releases promise even more layers to team-building, as inter-character relationship balancing (guards vs. inmates) and personalities will also play a role in pursuing (or avoiding) character combinations. Granted, the alpha is very short and misses out on giving you the chance to bring any long-term team-building strategies into play, and especially early-on you'll find yourself taking any character you come across just to keep your team's collective head above water. Having a really good team fall into place is more a matter of luck than planning. Hopefully later versions will realize the potential there.New players should be aware of just how short the game currently is. Dungeon of the *Endless* isn't really (endless, that is). Not yet. At only three levels it's a bit of a tease, one that lasts about an hour and a half even with obsessive exploration of every nook and cranny. I can hardly fault the developers though. They've told us what we'll find going in. The randomization of the levels (and recruitable character encounters) and the way the game still manages to throw curve-balls and stay challenging keeps me playing and giddily anticipating the masterpiece that this game will be if the developers deliver. The alpha is already amazing. I doubt we'll be disappointed.

												A neat and fun game that has many unique details in it, and yet it's definitely not flawless! I down voted this game originally thinking that the creators completely failed in their idea, but here I am more than a year later to come back to this game, enjoying it way better than I used to.Still I have to point out these things that are, in my opinion, not right:A playthrough takes way too long for a Rogue-like. It can take 3 to 4 hours to beat it. This makes trying out new chars and tactics a bit tedious. There is still quite a narrow range of strategies to have success in a playthrough.There is no proper tutorial.The multiplayer is a mess.(The gameplay is simply not compatible for multiplayer, you're better off alone)The thing that changed my mind are the free DLC and the welcoming tweaks to the balancing. Random scenarios are more common and more "friendly", so now you actually feel lucky from time to time. A mistake early on can be resolved later (it didn´t used to be like this). But hey, it costs between 12 and 20€ so I can forgive the mentioned cons.So I'm safe to say now that, if you are into these types of games, you'll get entertainment worth your money.

content:
Posted: September 17, 2015
What do I rate it? A significantly high 7/10.Why?In brief; it's an amazing dungeon crawler with a tower-defense aspect seamlessly and cleverly incorporated into the fighting aspect of the game between each round of opening a new random door. You could trawl the floors for hours and spend even longer over-thinking your strategic moves between rooms. After the fourth or fifth floor, you begin to feel a familiarity building and the game slowly becomes a little repetitive. Discovering the same rooms you did two floors ago - like a treasure room, banquet surprise (food bonus), scrap parts (factory parts) and yadda yadda. So although the maps are all unique and no path is the same as the last map, you begin to build a familiarity with the small number of different custom rooms you could venture into, which to an extent, makes you feel like there's nothing new to discover and you've seen everything already. Just in a different order between the floors you take.Multiplayer is nonexistent online. I've tried searching for public matches and to no avail found any. So the multiplayer aspect would only be feesible if you had friends who also the game to play with and don't mind spending a vast amount of time on a playthrough that you can't save or return too. As of yet anyway. Overall...?Yes. It's a game that will entertain you for hours if you enjoy dungeon crawlers. Do not buy for the mulitplayer aspect, unless someone else owns the game and can be relied upon to play with you for hours at a time to even attempt to finish a playthrough. Atmospherics, music and gameplay is fairly good. Overal; buy this game when it's on sale. I wouldn't say it's worth the retail mark-up and it definitely needs a lot of rough edges smoothing out. Such as bugs and incomplete fixes. But a very promising arcade style game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4, 2015
												A fantastic combination of tower defense with rpg and randomized elements. Each new pod you unlock changes the feel and play of the game to a great degree, making multiple playthroughs worthwhile, challenging and fun. Highly recommended.There is a definite learning curve, and it can take a few hours to get yourself going in a groove to get the feel for each unique escape pod's rules for success. The tutorial is lacking, but the guides aren't. If you're up for a challenge and the twoer defense and rogue like aspects are interesting to you, grab this. BE WARNED: the rogue-like aspects can mean you hit a floor you will need to play perfectly to beat, and you can lose a lot of progress for making a bad gamble. [and to some degree, the game can bone you with a punishing floor and there isn't much you can do if you get no dust (a type of currency) for like 9 rooms straight].

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 6, 2015
												If you like FTL you'll like this game.  It has elements of a lot of different types of games:  4x, Rogue-like, Tower Defense, etc.    The goal is to escape the dungeon floor by floor.    Each floor starts the same way, you and a power source.    You need to explore until you find the exit.   Then you need to plan a way to move the power source to the exit.   Moving said power source spawns a neverending slew of monsters.   Monsters spawn from unpowered areas so you can set up an escape route.   All the while you need to balance leveling your team (Food), researching modules (Science) and building defenses or resource generating modules.   I'm 0 for 7 on "Too Easy" so expect a challenge.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 12, 2015
												I picked this up in a pack along with Endless Legend and Space because I wanted to get into a new 4x game. This game wasn't on my radar before and I didn't really expect anything from it. However what I found was a surprisingly addictive roguelike that borrowed elements from a dozen other genres put together into a deceptively complex whole. I've only beaten the game once on "easy" (actually the game's hard difficulty) but doing that took nearly a dozen attempts worth of familiarizing myself with the mechanics and each time felt unique and "worth" it.The game's art and music style are very nice and the heroes are interesting, if not in terms of personality at least what they bring to the table in terms of options available to you each run. I feel like they'd work well in a more fully fleshed out RPG setting with expanded mechanics.It would be nice if there was some kind of persistence between tries outside of which heroes you have unlocked to start with as I do feel that is a barrier to replayability currently. However even with that said I feel like this game is more than worth the admission price. One of the most surprisingly enjoyable games I've played recently.
